note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scena prima:
div.stage: Enter the Duke of Orleans, and the Earle of Amiens at severall doores.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: MOrrow my Lord of Orleance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You salute me like a stranger; brother Orleance were to me a Title more belonging, whom you call the husband of your sister.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would the circumstances of your brotherhood had never offer'd cause to make our conversation lesse familiar: I meet you like a hinderance in your way: your great law suit is now upon the tongue, and ready for a judgement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Came you from the Hall now?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Without stay; the Court is full, and such a presse of people does attend the issue, as if some great man were brought to his araignment.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Every mothers sonne of all that multitude of hearers went to be a witnesse of the misery your sisters fortunes must have come to, if my adversary who did love her first, had been her husband.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The successe may draw a testimony from them to confirme the same opinion, but they went prepar'd with no such hope or purpose.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And did you intreat, the number of them that are come with no such hope or purpose.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Tush, your own experience of my heart can answer ye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: This doubtfull, makes me clearly understand your disposition.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: If your cause be just,
I wish you a conclusion like your cause.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I can have any common charity to such a prayer
From a friend I would expect a love to prosper in;
Without exceptions such a love as might
Make all my under takings thankfull to't;
Precisely just is seldome faithfull in our wishes
To another mans desires: Farewell. Exit Orl.

div.stage: Enter Montague having a Purse, Duboys, Longueville, and Voramer the Page with two Gaskets.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here comes your adversaries brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The Lord of Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: From the Hall I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I did so: save your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's a wish my Lord, as courteous to my present state,
As ever honest mind was thankfull for;
For now my safety must expose it selfe
To question: yet to look for any free
Or hearty salutation (sir from you)
Would be unreasonable in me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your sister is my adversaries wife;
That neernesse needs must consequently draw
Your inclination to him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I will grant
Him all the neernesse his alliance claimes,
And yet be nothing lesse impartiall
My Lord of Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord of Montague yet:
But (sir) how long the dignity or state
Belonging to it will continue, stands
Upon the dangerous passage of this houre,
Either for ever more to be confirm'd,
Or like the time wherein twas pleaded, gone:
Gone with it, never to be call'd again.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Justice direct your processe to the end;
To both your persons my respect shall stil
Be equall; but the righteous cause is that
Which bears my wishes to the side it holds,
Wherever may it prosper. Exit Amiens.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then my thanks
Are proper to you, if a man may raise
A confidence upon a lawfull ground
I have no reason to be once perplexed
With any doubtfull motion, Longueville,
That Lord of Amiens, (didst observe him?) has
A worthy nature in him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Either tis his nature or his cunning.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's the vizard of most mens actions,
Whose dissembled lives
Do carry onely the similitude
Of goodnesse on 'em, but for him
Honest behaviour makes a true report,
What disposition does inhabit him,
Essentiall vertue.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then tis pitty that
Injurious Orleance is his brother.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: He is but his brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Law? that's as bad.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How is your Law as bad? I rather wish
The hangman thy executor then that
Equivocation should be ominous.

div.stage: Enter two Lawyers, and two Creditors.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Some of your Lawyers.—

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: What is ominous?

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: Let no distrust trouble your Lordships thought.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: The evidences of your question'd land
Ha' not much as any literall
Advantage in 'em to be made against
Your title.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: And your Councell understands
The businesse fully.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Th'are industrious, just.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: And very confident.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Your state endures
A voluntary tryall; like a man
Whose honours are maliciously accus'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: The Accusation serves to cleare his cause.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: And to approve his truth more.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: So shall all
Your adversaries pleadings strengthen your
Possession.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: And be set upon record
To witnesse the hereditary right
Of you and yours.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: Courage, you have the law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you the profits.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If discouragement
Could worke upon me, your assurances
Would put me strongly into heart again;
But I was never fearfull: and let fate
Deceive my expectation, yet I am
Prepared against dejection.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: So are we.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: We have received a comfortable hope
That all will speed well.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What is he Duboys?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: A Creditor.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I thought so, for he speaks
As if he were a partner in his state.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir, I am largely indebted to your loves.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: More to their purses.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Which you shall not lose.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's another creditor.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Has interest in me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have more of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: And I have had so many promises
From these and all your learned Councellors,
How certainly your cause wil prosper: that—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You brought no Serjeants with you?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: To attend his ill successe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good sir, I will not be
Unthankfull either to their industries
Or your affections.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: All your land (my Lord)
Is at the bar now, give me but ten Crowns
Ile save you harmlesse.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Take him at his word;
If he does lose, you're sav'd by miracle,
For I never knew a lawyer yet undone.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Then now you shall sir, if this prospers not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you doe not force your voyce
To such a loudnesse, but be thrifty now;
Preserve it till you come to plead at bar
It wil be much more profitable in
The satisfaction then the promise.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Is not this a satisfaction to engage
My selfe for this assurance, if he—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No sir, my ruine never shall import
Anothers losse, if not by accident,
And that my purpose is not guilty of:
You are engaged in nothing but your care. Exit Law.
Attend the Procurator to the Court,
Observe how things incline, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare not sir; if I be taken there,
Mine eares will be in danger.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why? hast thou
Committed something that deserves thine eares?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, but I feare the noyse; my hearing will be
Perished by the noise; tis as good 't want
A member, as to loose the use—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The ornament is excepted.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Well my Lord
Ile put 'em to the hazzard. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your desires be prosperous to you.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: Our best prayers waite
Upon your fortune. Exeunt Cred.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: For your selves, not him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou canst not blame 'em: I am in their debts.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But had your large expence (a part whereof
You owe 'em) for unprofitable Silkes
And Laces, been bestowed among the poore,
That would have prayd the right way for you:
Not upon you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For unprofitable Silkes
And Laces? now believe me honest boy
Th'ast hit upon a reprehension that belongs
Unto me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: By— my Lord,
I had not so unmannerly a thought,
To reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why I love thee for't.
Mine own acknowledgement confirmes thy words:
For once I do remember, comming from
The Mercers, where my Purse had spent it selfe
On those unprofitable toyes thou speakst of,
A man halfe naked with his poverty
Did meet me, and requested my reliefe:
I wanted whence to give it, yet his eyes
Spoke for him, those I could have satisfied
With some unfruitfull sorrow, (if my teares
Would not have added rather to his griefe,
Then eas'd it) but the true compassion that
I should have given I had not: this began
To make me think how many such mens wants
The vaine superfluous cost I wore upon
My outside would have clothed, and left my selfe
A habit as becomming: to encrease
This new consideration there came one
Clad in a garment plaine and thrifty, yet
As decent as these faire deare follies; made
As if it were of purpose to despise
The vanity of show: his purse had still
The power to doe a charitable deed,
And did it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yet your inclination, sir,
Deservd no lesse to be commended, then his action.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Prethee do not flatter me;
He that intends well, yet deprives himselfe
Of means to put his good thoughts into deed,
Deceives his purpose of the due reward
That goodnesse merits: O antiquity
Thy great examples of Nobility
Are out of imitation, or at least
So lamely follow'd, that thou art as much
Before this age in vertue, as in time.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, it must needs be lamely followed, when
The chiefest men love to follow it
Are for the most part cripples.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Souldiers, my Lord, souldiers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Tis true Duboys: but if the Law disables me no more
For Noble actions, then good purposes,
Ile practice how to exercise the worth
Commended to us by our ancestors;
The poore neglected souldier shall command
Me from a Ladies Courtship, and the forme
Ile study shall no more be taught me by
The Taylor, but the Scholler; that expence
Which hitherto has been to entertaine
Th' intemperate pride and pleasure of the taste
Shall fill my Table more to satisfie,
And lesse to surfeit.
What an honest worke it would be; when we finde
A Virgin in her poverty, and youth
Inclining to be tempted, to imploy
As much perswasion, and as much expence
To keep her upright as men use to do upon her falling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Tis charity that many mayds wil be unthankful for,
And some will rather take it for a wrong,
To buy 'em out of their inheritance,
The thing that they were born to.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Longueville thou bringst a cheerfull promise in thy face.
There stands no pale report upon thy cheeke,
To give me feare or knowledge of my losse, tis red and lively.
How proceeds my suit?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: That's with labour sir, a labour that to those of Hercules
May adde another; or (at least) be cald
A imitation of this burning shirt:
For twas a paine of that unmercifull
Perplexity, to shoulder through the throng
Of people that attended your successe:
My sweaty linnen fixt upon my skin,
Still as they puld me, tooke that with it; 'twas
A feare I should have left my flesh among 'em:
Yet I was patient, for( me thought) the toyle
Might be an emblem of the difficult
And weary passage to get out of Law.
And to make up the deare similitude,
When I was forth seeking my handkircher
To wipe my sweat off, I did finde a cause
To make me sweat more, for my Purse was lost
Among their finger.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There twas rather found.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By them.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I mean so.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Well, I will restore
Thy dammage to thee: how proceeds my suit?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.l: Like one at Brokers; I thinke forfeited.
Your promising councell at the first
Put strongly forward with a labour'd speed,
And such a violence of pleading, that
His fee in Sugar-candie scarce will make
His throat a satisfaction for the hurt
He did it, and he carried the whole cause
Before him with so cleare a passage, that
The people in the favour of your side
Cried Montague, Montague: in the spight of him
That cryed out silence, and began to laugh
Your adversaries Advocate to scorn:
Who like a cunning foot-man? set me forth
With such a temperate easie kind of course
To put him into exercise of strength,
And follow'd his advantages so close,
That when your hot mouthed pleader thought 'had wonne,
Before he reacht it, he was out of breath,
And then the other stript him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So all is lost.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But how I know not; for( me thought) I stood
Confounded with the clamour of the Court,
Like one embarqued upon a storm at Sea,
Where the tempestuous noise of Thunder mixt
With roaring of the billows, and the thick
Imperfect language of the Sea-men, takes
His understanding and his safety both
Together from him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou dost bring ill news

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Of what I was unwilling to have been
The first reporter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Didst observe no more?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: At least no better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then th' art not inform'd
So well as I am; I can tell thee that
Will please thee, for when all else left my cause,
My very adversaries tooke my part.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: — whosoever told you that abused you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Credit me, he took my part
When all forsook me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Took it from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes I meane so, and I think he had just cause
To take it when the verdict gave it him.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: His Spirit would ha' sunke him, ere he could
Have carried an ill fortune of this waight so lightly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nothing is a misery unlesse our weaknesse apprehend it so;
We cannot be more faithfull to our selves
In any thing that's manly, then to make
Ill fortune as contemptible to us
As it makes us to others.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Here come they
Whose very countenances will tell you how
Contemptible it is to others.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The sir of Knighthood may be given him, ere
They heare you now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good sir but a word.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How soon the losse of wealth makes any man
Grow out of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let me see I pray sir,
Never stood you upon the pillory?

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: The Pillory?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O now I know you did not.
Y'ave eares, I thought ye had lost 'em; pray observe,
Here's one that once was gracious in our eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: O my Lord, have an eye upon him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But ha' you nere a Counsell to redeeme
His Land yet from the judgement?

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: None but this, a writ of errour to remove the cause.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No more of errour, we have been in that too much already.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.p: If you will reverse the judgement, you must trust to that delay.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Delay? Indeed he's like to trust to that,
With you has any dealing.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.p: Ere the Law proceeds to an habere facias possessionem.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's a language sir, I understand not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Th'art a very strange unthankfull fellow to have taken Fees of such a liberall measure, and then give a man hard words for's money.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: If men will hazzard their salvations,
What should I say? I've other businesse.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Y'are ith' right;
That's it you should say now prosperity has left me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Have an eye upon him; if
We lose him now, he's gone for ever; stay
And dog him: Ile goe fetch the officers.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Dog him you blood-hound: by this point thou shalt more safely dog an angry Lion then attempt him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Doe but steere to fetch a Serjeant; and (besides your losse
Of labour) Ile have you beaten, till
Those casements in your faces be false lights.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Falser then those you sell by.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who gave you Commission to abuse my friends thus?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Sir, are those your friends that would betray you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Tis to save themselves rather then betray me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your Lordship makes a just construction of it.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: All our desire is but to get our own.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your wives desires and yours do differ then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So far as my ability will goe
You shall have satisfaction Longeville,

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And leave your selfe neglected; every man
Is first a debtor to his own demands, being honest.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As I take it sir, I did
Not entertaine you for my counsellor.

sp.speaker: Ilong.
sp.l: Counsel's the office of a servant,
When the master fals upon a danger: as
Defence is never threaten with your eyes,
They are no cockatrices; do you heare?
Talke with a Girdler, or a Milner,
He can informe you of a kind of men
That first undid the profit of those trades
By bringing up the forme of carrying
There morglachs in their hands: with some of those
A man may make himselfe a priviledge
To aske a question at the prison gates,
Without your good permission.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: By your leave.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stay sir, what one example since the time
That first you put your hat off to me, have
You noted in me to encourage you
To this presumption? by the justice now
Of thine own rule, I should begin with thee,
I should turn thee away ungratified
For all thy former kindnesse, forget
Thou ever didst me any service: tis not feare
Of being arrested makes me thus incline
To satisfie you; for you see by him,
I lost not all defences with my state;
The curses of a man to whom I am
Beholding terrifie me more, then all
The violence he can pursue me with.
Duboys, I did prepare me for the worst;
These two small Cabinets doe comprehend
The sum of all the wealth that it hath pleased
Adversity to leave me, one as rich
As th' other, both in Jewels; take thou this,
And as the Order put within it shall
Direct thee, distribute it half between
Those Creditors, and th' other halfe among
My servants: for (sir) they are my creditors
As well as you are, they have trusted me
With their advancement: if the value faile,
To please you all, my first increase of meanes
Shall offer you a fuller payment; be content
To leave me something, and imagine that
You put a new beginner into credit.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: So prosper our own blessings, as we wish you to your merit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Are your silences of discontent, or of sorrow?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, we would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Do but suffer us to follow you, and what our present means, or industries hereafter can provide, shall serve you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O desire me not to live
To such a basenesse, as to be maintained
By those that serve me; pray be gone, I wil
Defend your honesties to any man
That shal report you have forsaken me;
I pray be gone. Exeunt Servants and Crediers.
Why dost thou weep my boy,
Because I doe not bid thee goe too?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No, I weep (my Lord) because I would not goe;
I feare you will command me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No my child,
I wil not; that would discommend th'intent
Of all my other actions: thou art yet
Unable to advise thy selfe a course,
Should I put thee to seeke it; after that
I must excuse or at the least forgive
Any uncharitable deed that can be done against my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Every day (my Lord) I tarry with you, Ile account
A day of blessing to me; for I shall
Have so much lesse time left me of my life
When I am from you: and if misery
Befall you (which I hope so good a man
Was never born to) I wil take my part,
And make my willingnesse increase my strength
To beare it. In the Winter I will spare
Mine own clothes from my selfe to cover you;
And in the Summer, carry some of yours
To ease you: Ile doe any thing I can.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why, thou art able to make misery
Ashamed of hurting, when thy weaknesse can
Both beare it, and despise it: Come my boy
I will provide some better way for thee
Then this thou speakst of; tis the comfort that
Ill fortune has undone me into the fashion:
For now in this age most men do begin,
To keep but one boy, that kept many men. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Orleans, a Servant, his Ladie following.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Where is she? call her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your friend sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What friend, good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your Montague, Madam, he will shortly want
Those Courtly graces that you love him for;
The means wherewith he purchased this, and this,
And all his own provisions to the least
Proportion of his feeding or his clothes,
Came out of that inheritance of land
Which he unjustly lived on: but the law
Has given me right in't, and possession; now
Thou shalt perceive his bravery vanish, as
This Jewell does from thee now, and these Pearles
To him that owes 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ye are the owner sir of every thing that does belong to me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: No, not of him, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O good God!

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: But in a while your mind will change, and be
As ready to disclaime him; when his wants
And miseries have perish'd his good face,
And taken off the sweetnesse that has made
Him pleasing in a womans understanding.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O Heaven, how gratious had Creation been
To women, who are borne without defence,
If to our hearts there had been doores through which
Or husbands might have lookt into our thoughts,
And made themselves undoubtfull.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Made 'em madde.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With honest women.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou dost still pretend
A title to that vertue: prethee let
Thy honesty speak freelie to me now.
Thou knowest that Montaigue of whose Land
I am the master, did affect three first,
And should have had thee, if the strength of friends
Had not prevail'd above thine own consent.
I have undone him; tell me how thou doest
Consider his ill fortune and my good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile tell you justly his iundoing is
An argument for pitty? and for teares
In all their dispositions that have known
The honour and the goodnesse of his life:
Yet that addition of prosperity,
Which you have got by't, no indifferent man
Will malice or repine at, if the Law
Be not abused in 't; howsoever since
You have the upper fortune of him, 'twill
Be some dishonour to you to beare your selfe
With any pride or glory over him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: This may be truly spoken, but in thee
It is not honest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes, so honest, that I care not if the chast Penelope
Were now alive to hear me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Who comes there?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Save yee.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now sir, you have heard of prosperous Montague.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No sir, I have heard of Montague,
But of your prosperity.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is he distracted.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He does beare his losse with such a noble strength
Of patience that,
Had fortune eyes to see him, she would weepe
For having hurt him, and pretending that
Shee did it but for triall of his worth:
Hereafter ever love him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I perceive you love him, and because (I must confesse)
He does deserve that though for some respects,
I have not given him that acknowledgement,
Yet in mine honour I did still conclude to use him nobly.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, that will become your reputation and make me grow proud of your alliance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I did reserve the doing of this friendship till I had
His fortunes at my mercy, that the world
May tell him 'tis a willing courtesie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This change wil make me happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Tis a change; thou shalt behold it, then observe me when
That Montague had possession of my Land,
I was his rivall, and at last obtain'd
This Lady who by promise of her own
Affection to him, should ha bin his wife;
I had her, and withheld her like a pawne,
Till now my Land is rendred to me againe,
And since it is so, you shall see I have
The conscience not to keep her— give him her— draws
For by the faithfull temper of my sword, shee shall not tarry with me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Give me way— draws.
Thou most unworthy man— give me way
Or by the wrong he does the Innocent,
Ile end thy misery and his wickednesse, together.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Stay and let me justifie
My husband in that, I have wrong'd his bed
sp.stage: Enter Amiens in amazement, the servants following him.
sp.l: Never— all shames that can afflict me fall
Upon me if I ever wrong'd you;

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Didst thou not confesse it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Twas to save your bloud from shedding, that has
Turn'd my brothers edge;
He that beholdes our thoughts as plainely as
Our faces, knowes it, I did never hurt
My honesty but by accusing it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Womens consents are sonner credited
Then their denials: and Ile never trust
Her body that prefers any defence
Before the safety of her honour— here— Enter servant
Show forth that stranger— give me not a word
Thou seest a danger readie to be tempted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Cast that upon me rather then my shame,
And as I am now dying I wil now—
That I am honest.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Put her out of dores; but that I feare my land
May go againe to Montague, I would kill thee, I am loth,
To make a beggar of him that way; or else—
Go now you have the liberty of flesh,
And you may put it to a double use,
One for your pleasure, th'other to maintaine
Your welbeloved, he wil want. Exit Lady
In such a charitable exercise
The vertue wil excuse you for the vice. Exit Orleans.

div.stage: Enter Amiens drawne, Montague, Vercamor meeting.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What meanes your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: For the love of God—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thou hast advantage of mee, cast away this buckler.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So he is Sir, for he lives
With one that is undone— a voyd us boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ile first avoid my safety,
Your Rapier shall be button'd, with my heade before it touch my Master.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my sister?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: For a whore?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You lye, and shall lie lower if you dare abuse her honor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am honest.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Honest!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Upon my faith I am.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What did then perswade thee to condemn thy self?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your safety.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I had rather be expos'd
To danger, then dishonor; th'ast betray'd
The reputation of my familie
More basely by the falsenesse of that word,
Then that thou hast delivered me asleepe
Into the hands of base enemie.
Reliefe will never make thee sensible
Of thy disgraces; let thy wants compell thee to it. Exit

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O I am a miserable woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why Madam? are you utterly without means to relieve you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I have nothing sir, unlesse by changing of these cloaths for worse, and then at last the worst for nakednesse.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stand off boy, nakednesse would be a change
To please us Madam, to delight us both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What nakednesse sir?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why the nakednesse of body Madam, we were Lovers once.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Never dishonest Lovers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Honestie has no allowance now to give our selves.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor you allowance against honestie.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ile send my Boy hence, opportunitie
Shall be our servant, come and meet me first
With kisses like a stranger at the doore,
And then invite me neerer to receive
A more familiar inward welcome— where,
Instead of tapers made of Virgins wax
Th'increasing flames of our desires shall light
Us to a banquet: and before the taste
Be dull with satisfaction, Ile prepare
A nourishment compos'd of every thing
That beares a naturall friendship to the bloud,
And that shall set another edge upon't,
Or else between the courses of the feast
Wee'l dallie out an exercise of time,
That ever as one appetite expires another may succeede it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O my Lord, how has your nature lost her worthinesse?
When our affections had their liberty,
Or kisses met as temperatelie as
The hands of sisters, or of brothers, that
Our blouds were then as moving; then you were
So noble, that I durst have trusted your
Embraces in an opportunity
Silent enough to serve a ravisher,
And yet come from you— undishonor'd— how
You think me altered, that you promise your
Attempt successe I know not; but were all
The sweet temptations that deceive us set
On this side, and one that side all the waiters,
These neither should perswade me nor the force.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then misery may waste your body.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, but lust shall never.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have found you still as uncorrupted as I left you first
Continue so; and I wil serve you with
As much devotion as my word, my hand
Or purse can show you; and to justifie
That promise, here is half the wealth I have,
Take it, you owe me nothing, till you fall
From vertue, which the better to protect
I have bethought me of a present meanes
Give me the Letter; this commends my Boy
Into the service of a Lady, whose
Free goodnesse you have bin acquainted with Lamira.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir I know her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then believe her entertainment wil be noble to you;
My boy shall bring you thither: and relate
Your manner of misfortune if your own
Report needs any witnesse: so I kisse your hand good Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to promise, but I cannot be unthankfull.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All that you can implore in thankfulnesse
Be yours, to make you the more prosperous.
Farwell my boy,— I am not yet oppress'd. Exit Lady Vera.
Having the power to helpe one that's distress'd.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What shall we do now: swords are out of use,
And words are out of credit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: We must serve.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The meanes to get a service will first spend
Our purses; and except we can allow
Our selves an entertainment, service will
Neglect us; now tis grown into a doubt
Whether the Mr. or the servant gives the countenance.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Then fall in with Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They keep more servants now (indeed) then men,
But yet the age is grown so populous
Of those attendants, that the women are
Grown full to.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: What shall we propund our selves?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'le think on't.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Do; Old occupations have too many setters up to prosper, some uncommon trade would thrive now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Wee'l ee'n make up some half a dozen proper men,
And should not we get more
Then all your female sinners?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: If the house be seated as it should be privately.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I but that would make a multitude of witches.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Witches? how prethee?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thus the bands would all turn witches to revenge
Themselves upon; us and the women that
Come to us, for disguises must wear beards,
And that's they say, a token of a witch.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: What shall we then do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We must study on't,
With more consideration; stay Duboyes
Are not the Lord of Orleans and the Lord
Of Amiens enemies?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yes, what of that.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Methinks the factions of two such great men.
Should give a promise of advancement now
To us that want it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let the plot be thine, and in the enterprize Ile second thee.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I have it, wee will first set down our selves
The Method of a quarrell; and make choyce
Of some frequented Taverne; or such a place
Of common notice to perform it in
By way of undertaking to maintaine
The severall honours of those enemies.
Thou for the Lord of Orleanes; I for Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I like the project, and I think 'twill take
The better, since their difference first did rise
From his occasion whom we followed once.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We cannot hope lesse after the report,
Then entertainment or gratuity,
Yet those are ends, I do not aime at most;
Greater spirits that are needy, and will thrive,
Must labour whiles such troubles are alive. Exeunt

sp.speaker: La p.
sp.p: Slander is sharper then the sword. I have fed this three dayes upon leafe Tobacco, for want of other Victuals.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You have liv'd the honester Captaine; but be not so dejected, but hold up thy head, and meate wil sooner fall i'thy mouth.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I care not so much for meat, so I had but good liquor, for which my guts croak like so many Frogs for raine.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It seemes, you are troubled with the wind-Collick Captaine, swallow a bullet: tis present remedy I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: A bullet; if you be Captain, my panch is nothing but a pile of bullets; when I was in any service I stood between my Generall and the shot, like a mud-wall; I am all lead, from the crown of the head to the soale of the foot, not a sound bone about me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It seems you have bin in terrible hot service Captaine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It has ever bin the fate of the low Country wars to spoile many a man, I ha' not bin the first nor shall not be the last: but Ile tell you sir, (hunger has brought it in to minde) I served once at the Siege of Braste 'tis memorable to this day, where we were in great distresse for victuals, whole troops fainted more for want of food then for blood, and died, yet we were resolved to stand it out; I my self was but then Gentleman of a Company, and had as much need as any man, and indeed I had perished had not a miraculous providence preserved me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: As how good Captaine?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Marry sir ee'n as I was fainting and falling down for want of sustenance, the enemy made a shot at me, and struck me full ith' paunch with a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Instead of a bullet!

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: In stead of a bullet.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: That was miraculous in deed; and that loaf sustained you.

sp.speaker: Lap-p.
sp.p: Nourished me or I had famished with the rest.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You have done worthy acts being a souldier, and now you shall give me leave to requite your tale, and to acquaint you with the most notorious deeds that I have done being a Courtier. I protest Captain I wil lie no more then you have done.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I can indure no lies.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I know you cannat Captaine, therefore Ile only tell you of strange things, I did once a deed of charity for it self; I assisted a poor widdow in a sute, and obtained it, yet I protest I took not a penny for my labour.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Tis no such strange thing.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By Mars Captaine, but it is, and a very strange thing too in a Courtier, it may take the upper hand of your penny loaf for a miracle. I could ha' told you how many Ladies have languished for my love, and how I was once sollicited by the mother, the daughter, and grand-mother out of the least of which I might have digg'd my selfe a fortune; they were all great Ladies, for two of them were so big I could hardly embrace them: but I was sluggish in my rising courses, and therefore let them passe; what meanes I had is spent upon such as had the wit to cheat me; That wealth being gon, I have only bought experience with it, with a strong hope to cheat others; but see here comes the much declined Montague, who had all the Man or houses, which were the body of his estate overthrowen by a great winde.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: How by a great winde? was he not over thrown by law?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Yes, marry was he: but there was terrible puffing and blowing before he was overthrown, if you observ'd, and believe it Captain, ther's no wind so dangerous to a building as a lawyers breath.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: What's he with him?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: An eminent Citizen. Mounsier Mallicorne, lets stand a side and listen their design.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir, profit is the Crown of labour, it is the life, the soule of the industrious Merchant, in it he makes his paradise, and for it neglects Wife, Children, Friends, Parents, nay all the world, and delivers up himselfe to the violence of stormes, and to be tos'd into unknown ayres; as there is no faculty so perillous, so ther's none so worthy profitable.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Sir, I am very well possest of it, and what of my poore fortunes remaines, I would gladly hazzard upon the Sea; it cannot deale worse with me then the Land, though it sinck or throw it in the hands of Pirats. I have yet five hundred pounds left, and your honest and worthy acquaintance may make me a young Merchant; th'one moity of what I have I would gladly adventure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How adventure? you shall hazzard nothing: you shall only joyne with me in certaine commodities that are safe arrived unto the Key; you shall neither be in doubt of danger nor dammage; But so much mony disburst, so much receive; sir I would have you conceive I pursue it not for any good your money wil do me, but meerly out of mine own freenesse and courtesie to pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I can believe no lesse, and you expresse a noble nature, seeking to build up a man so ruin'd as my selfe.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Captaine here is subject for us to worke upon if we have wit; you hear that there is money yet left, and it is going to be layd out in Rattels, Bels, Hobby-Horses, brown paper, or some such like sale commodities; now it would do better in our purses, upon our backs in good Gold-lace, and Scarlet, and then we might pursue our projects, and our devices towards my Lady Annabella; go to, ther's a conceit newly landed; harck I stand in good reputation with him, and therefore may the better cheat him: Captaine, take a few instructions from me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What monies I have is at your disposing, and upon twelve I will meete you at the Pallace with it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I wil there expect you, and so I take my leave. Exit

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You apprehend me?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Why do ye think I am a dunce?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Not a dunce Captaine, but you might give me leave to misdoubt that pregnancy in a Souldier, which is proper and hereditary to a Courtier; but prosequute it, I wil both second, and give credit to it. Good Mounsier Montague, I would your whole revenues lay within the circuit of mine armes, that I might as easily bestow, or restore it unto you as my curtesie.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: My zealous wishes sir, do accompany his for your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Believe it sir, our affection towards you is a strong band of friendship.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: To which I shall most willingly seale. But believe me Gentlemen in a broken estate, the bond of friendship oft is forfeited, but that it is your free and ingenuous nature to renew it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Sir, I wil amply extend my self to your use, and am very zealously afflicted as not one of your least friends for your croocked fate; But let it seise you with any dejection, you have as I hear a sufficient competency left, which wel disposed may erect you as high in the worlds account as ever.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I cannot live to hope it, much lesse injoy it, nor
is it any part of my endeavour; my study is to render every man his own, and to containe my self within the limits of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I have the grant of an Office given me by some noble favorites of mine in Court, there stands but a small matter between me and it, if your ability be such to lay down the present sum, out of the love I bear you, before any other man, it shall be confirmed yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I have heard you often speak of such a thing; if it be assur'd to you I wil gladly deale in it that portion I have, I would not hazard upon one course, for I see the most certainest is incertain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Having money sir, you could not light upon men that could give better direction; there is at this time a friend of mine upon the Seas; to be plain with you, he is a Pyrate, that hath wrote to me to work his fredom, and by this Gentlemans meanes, whose acquaintance is not small at Court; we have the word of a worthy man for it, only there is some money to be suddainly disburst, and if your happinesse be such to make it up you shall receive treble gaine by it, and good assurance for it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Gentlemen out of the weaknesse of my estate you seem (to have some knowledge of my brest) that wood if it were possible advance my declined fortunes, to satisfie all men of whom I have had credit, and I know no way better then these which you propose; I have some money ready under my command, some part of it is already promis'd, but the remainder is yours to such uses as are propounded.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Appoint some certain place of meeting, for these affaires requires expedition.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I wil make it my present businesse: at twelve, I am to meet Mallicorne the Marchant at the Pallace, you know him sir, about some negotiation of the same nature, there I wil be ready to tender you that money, upon such conditions as wee shall conclude off.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The care of it be yours, so much as they affaire concernes you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Your caution is effectuall, and till then I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good Mr Montague. Exit

div.stage: Whithin a elamor, down with their weapons. Enter Longavile and Dubois, their swords drawn, servants and others between them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen what meane you pray be quiet, have some respect unto the house.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A treacherous slave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Thou dost revile thy self base Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I say thou art a villaine and a corrupt one, that hast some seaven years fed on thy masters trencher, yet never bredst good bloud towards him: for if, thou hadst have a sounder heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: So sir, you can use your tongue something nimbler then your sword.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Wood you cood use your tongue well of your Master, friend you might have better imployment for your sword.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I say againe and I wil speak it loud and often, that Orleans is a noble Gentleman with whom Amiens is to light to poyse the scale.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: He is the weaker for taking of a prayse out of thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: This hand shall seale his merit at thy heart.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Part them my masters part them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Part them sir, why do you not part them, you stand by with your sword in your hand, and cry part 'em.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why you must know my friend my cloaths are better then yours, and in a good suit, I do never use to part any body.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And it is discretion.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I marry is it Captaine.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Duboies though this place priviledge thee, know where next we meet, the bloud which at thy heart flowes drops at thy feet.

div.stage: Enter Amience in hast, his sword drawne.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would not spend it better then in this quarrell, and on such a hazard.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: What uprores this, must my name here be question'd in Tavern brawels, and by affected Ruffins?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Not we indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Fear cannot make me shrink out of your fury, though you were greater then your name doth make you, I am one, and the opposer; if your swoln rage have ought in mallice to inforce expresse it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I seek thee not nor shalt thou ever gaine
That credit, which a blow from me wood give thee,
By my— I more detest that fellow
Which took my part then thee, that he durst offer
To take my honour in his feeble armes,
And spend it in a drinking room; which way went he?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: That way sir, I wood you wood after for I do fear we shall have some more scuffling.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Ile follow him, and if my speed o're take him,
I shall ill thank him for his forwardnesse. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I am glad he's gon, for I do not love to see a sword drawn in the hand of a man that lookes so furious, ther's no jesting with edge tooles, how say you Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I Say tis better jesting then to be in earnest with them. Enter Orleance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How now? what's the difference? they say there have bin swords drawn, and in my quarrell, let me know that man, whose love is so sincere to spend his bloud for my sake, I will bounteously requite him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: We were all of your side, but there he stands begun it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Duboyes?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou hast receaved no hurt?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Not any, nor wear this body stuck full of wounds, I should not count them hurts, being taken in so honorable a cause as the defence of my most worthy Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The dedication of thy love to me requires my ample bounty, thou art mine, for I do finde thee made unto my purposes. Mounsieur Laverdine, pardon my neglect I not observed you, and how runs rumour.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why, it runs my Lord like a foot man without a cloak, to show that what's once rumour'd it cannot be hidde.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And what say the rable, am not I the subject of their talk?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Troth my Lord the common mouth speakes foule words.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Of me, for turning away thy wife do they not?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Faith the men do a little murmer at it and say, 'tis an ill president in so great a man, marry the women they rayle, out right.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Out upon them rampallions Ile keepe my selfe safe enough out of their fingers, but what say my prity
Jelly composed gallant that censure every thing more desperate then it is dangerous; what say they?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Marry they are laying wagers, what death you shall die; one offers to lay five hundred pounds; And yet he had but a groat about him, & that was in two two-pences too to any man that wo'd make it up a shilling; that you were kil'd with a Pistoll charg'd with white Powder; another offerd to pawne his soule for five shillings, and yet no body wo'd take him, that you were stab'd to death and sho'd die with more wounds then Cesar.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And who sho'd be the Butchers that sho'd do it? Montague and his associates?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: So tis conjectured.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And believe it, sweet Prince, it is to be feared, and therefore prevented.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: By turning his purpose on himself, were not that the way?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The most direct path for your safety. For where doth danger sit more furious then in a desperate man?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And being you have declined his meanes, you have increast his malice.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Besides the generall report that steems in every mans breath, and staines you all over with infamy, that Time the devourer of all things cannot eat out.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I, for that former familiarity, which he had with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Men speak it as boldly as words of complement; good morrow, good even, or God save you sir, are not more usuall; if the word cuckold had been written upon your forehead in great Capitall Letters, it could not have been dilated with more confidence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He shall not sleepe another night, I will have his blood, though it be required at my hands again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Your Lordship may, and without hazzarding your own person; he's a Gentleman in whose looks I see a resolution to perform it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let his Lordship give me but his honourable word for my life, Ile kill him as he walks.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or pistoll him as he sits at meat.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Or at game.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or as he is drinking.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Any way.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Wot thou? call what is mine thine own, thy reputation shall not be brought in question for it, much lesse thy life; it shall be namd a deed of valour in thee, not murder: Farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I need no more encouragement, it is a worke I will perswade my selfe that I was borne to.

sp.speaker: Laver.
sp.p: And you may perswade your selfe to that you shall be sav'd by it, being that it is for his honourable Lordship.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But you must yield me means, how, when and where.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: That shall be bur taskes;
Nay more, we will be agents with thee:
This houre we are to meet him, on the receipt of certain moneys,
Which indeed we purpose honestly to cheat him of,
And that's the many causes I wo'd have him slain,
Who works with safety makes a double gain. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Stay sir, I have took some pains to overtake you.
— You name is Longaville?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I have the word of many honest men for't, I crave your Lordships pardon, your sudden apppehension on my steps made me to frame an answer unwitting and unworthy your respect.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Doe you know me?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I know not you; nor am I well pleased to make this time, as the affaire now stands, the induction of your acquaintance; you are a fighting fellow?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I thinke I too much grace you; rather you are a fellow dares not fight, but spet and puffe and make a noyse whilst your trembling hand drawes out your Sword, to lay it upon Andirons, stooles or tables, rather then on a man.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your honour may best speake this; yet— with little safety, if I thought it serious.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Come, you are a merry braggart, and you have given me cause to tell you so: what weaknesse have you ever seen in me to prompt your selfe, that I could need your helpe, or what other reasons could induce you to it? you never yet had a meales meat from my Table, nor as I remember from my Wardrop any cast Suite.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Tis true, I never durst yet have such a service spirit, to be the minion of a full swolne Lord; but alwaies did detest such slavery: a meales meat, or a cast sute? I wo'd first eate the stones, and from such rags the dunghils does afford pick me a garment.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I have mistook the man, his resolute spirit
Proclaimes him generous, he has a noble heart
As free to utter good deeds as to act them;
For had he not been right, and of one piece,
He would have crumpled, curled, and struck himselfe
Out of the shape of man into a shaddow.
But prethee tell me, if no such fawning hope
Did lead thee on to hazzard life for my sake;
What was it that incited thee?
Tell me; speak it without the imputation of a Sicophant.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your own desert, and with it was joyn'd the unfained friendship that I judged you ever held unto my former Lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The noble Montague?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, the noble and much injured Montague.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: To such a man as thou art, my heart shall be
A Casket: I will lock thee up there,
And esteem thee as a faithfull friend,
The richest Jewell that a man enjoyes;
And being thou didst follow once my friend,
And in thy heart still dost, not with his fortunes casting him off,
Thou shalt goe hand in hand with me, and share
As well in my ability as love; tis not my end
To gaine men for my use, but a true friend. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There's no such thriving way to live in grace,
As to have no sence of it; his backe nor belly
Shall not want warming that can practise me mischiefe;
I walke now with a full purse, grow high and wanton,
Prune and briske my selfe in the bright shine
Of his good Lordships favours; and for what vertue?
For fashioning my selfe a murderer.
O noble Montague, to whom I owe my heart,
With all my best thoughts, tho my tongue have promisd
To exceed the malice of thy destiny,
Never in time of all my service knew I
Such a sinne tempt thy bounty; those that did feed
Upon thy charge had merit or else need.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Lapoope, with disguises.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Duboys, most prosperously met.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: How now? will he come this way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: This way, immediately; therefore thy assistance, deere Duboys.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: What have you cheated him of the money you spoke of?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Fough, as easily as a filly Countrey wench of her maydenhead; we had it in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Tis well Captaine, let me helpe you, you must be our leader in this action.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Tut, feare not, Ile warrant you if my Sword hold, we'l make no sweating sicknesse of it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Why that's well said, but let's retire a little, that we may come on the more bravely; this way, this way.

div.stage: Enter Montague in the hands of three Officers, and three Creditors.

sp.speaker: 1 Cre.
sp.p: Officers look to him, and be sure you take good security before he part from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why but my friends, you take a strange course with me; the sums I owe you are rather forgetfulnesse they are so slight, then want of will or honesty to pay you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: I sir, it may be so; but we must be paid, and we will be paid before you scape: we have wife and children, and a charge, and you are going down the wind, as a man may say; and therefore it behooves us to looke to't in time.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Your cloak here wo'd satisfie me, mine's not above a three pound matter, besides the arrest.

sp.speaker: 3 Cred.
sp.p: Faith and mine is much about that matter too; your Girdle and Hangers, and your Beaver, shall be sufficient baile for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: If you have ever a plain black sute at home, this Silken one, with your Silke-stockings, Garters, and Roses shall pacifie me too; for I take no delight, if I have a sufficient pawne, to cast any Gentleman in prison; therefore tis but an untrussing matter, and you are free, we are no unreasonable creatures you see; for mine own part, I protest I am loth to put you to any trouble for security.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Is there no more of you? he wo'd next demand my skinne.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: No sir, here's no more of us, nor do any of us demand your skin, we know not what to doe with it: but it may be if you ow'd your Glover any money, he knew what use to make of it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ye dregs of basenesse, vultures amongst men,
That tyer upon the hearts of generous spirits.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: You doe us wrong sir, we tyre no generous spirits, we tyre nothing but our hackneys.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But here comes one made of another piece;
A man well meriting that free born name
Of Citizen; welcome my deliverer, I am falne
Into the hands of blood-hounds, that for a sum
Lesser then their honesties, which is nothing,
Wo'd teare me out of my skin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 Cre.
sp.p: Why sir, the matter is, that we must have our money, which if we cannot have, we'l satisfie our selves with his carcasse, and be payd that waies: you had as good sir not have been so peremptory. Officer, hold fast.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: The strenuous fist of vengeance now is clutcht; therefore feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What may be the debt in grosse?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Some forty Crowns, nay rather not so much, tis quickly cast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis strange to me, that your estate sho'd have so low an ebbe, to sticke at such sleight sums: why my friends, you are too strict in your accounts, and call too sudden on this Gentleman, he has hopes left yet to pay you all.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Hopes? I marry bid him pay his friends with hopes, and pay us with currant Coyne: I knew a gallant once that fed his creditors still with hopes, and bid 'em they sho'd feare nothing, for he had 'em tyed in a string; and trust me so he had indeed, for at last he and all his hopes hopt in a haltar.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Good sir, with what speed you may free out the company of these slaves, that have nothing but their names to show 'em men.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What wo'd you wish me do sir? I protest I ha' not the present summe (small as it is) to lay down for you; and for giving my word, my friends no latter then yesternight made me take bread and eate it, that I sho'd not do it for any man breathing ith' world; therefore I pray bold me excused.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You doe not speake this seriously?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As ever I said my prayers, I protest to you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What may I think of this?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Troth sir thought is free for any man; we abuse our betters in it, I have done it my selfe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Trust me, this speech of yours doth much amaze me, pray leave this language, and out of that same sum you lately did receive of me, lay down as much as may discharge me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You are a merry man sir, and I am glad you take your crosses so temperately; fare you well sir, and yet I have something more to say to ye, a word in your eare I pray; to be plaine with you I did lay this plot to arrest you to enjoy this money I have of yours, with the more safety. I am a foole to tell you this now; but in good faith I could not keepe it in. And the money wo'd a done me little good else. An honest Citizen cannot wholly enjoy his own wife for you, they grow old before they have true use of them, which is a lamentable thing, and truely much hardens the hearts of us Citizens against you: I can say no more, but am heartily sorry for your heavinesse, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Officers take hold on him againe, for Mounsier
Mallycorne will doe nothing for him I perceive.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Nay come my masters, leave dauncing of the old measures, and let's assault him bravely.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By no means; for it goes against my stomacke to kill a man in an unjust quarrell.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It must needs be a clog to a mans conscience all his life time.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It must indeed Captaine: besides doe ye not see he has gotten a guard of friends about him, as if he had some knowledge of our purpose?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Had he a guard of Devils as I think them little better, my Sword should doe the message that it came for.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: If you will be so desperate, the blood lie upon your own neck, for we'l not meddle in't.

div.stage: Duboys runs upon Montague, and strugling yeelds him his Sword; the Officers draw, Laverdine and La-poope in the scuffling retire, Montague chaseth them off the Stage, himselfe wounded.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I am your friend and servant,
Struggle with me and take my Sword;
Noble sir make your way, you have slaine an Officer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Some one of them has certainly
Requited me; for I do lose much blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Udsprecious, we have lost a brother, pursue the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Offic.
sp.p: Ile not meddle with him: you see what comes on't; besides I know he will be hang'd ere he be taken.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: I tell thee yeoman he must be taken ere he be hanged; he is hurt in the guts, run afore therefore and know how his wife will rate his Sawsiges a pound.

sp.speaker: 3 Offic.
sp.p: Stay brother, I may live, for surely I finde i'm but hurt in the leg a dangerous kick on the shin-bone.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Madam Lamira, Madam le Orleans, Veramour.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You see Lady
What harmlesse sports our Countrey life affords;
And though you meet not here with City dainties,
Or Courtly entertainment, what you have
Is free and hearty.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, I finde here
What is a stranger to the Court, content,
And receive curtesies done for themselves,
Without an expectation of returne,
Which binds me to your service.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Oh your love;
My homely house built more for use then shew
Observes the Golden mean equally distant
From glittering pompe, and sordid avarice;
For Maskes we will observe the workes of nature
And in the place of visitation read.
Our Physick shall be wholsome walkes, our viandes,
Nourishing not provoking: for I finde
Pleasures are tortures, that leave stings behind.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: You have a great estate.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A competency
Sufficient to maintaine me and my ranke,
Nor am I, I thank Heaven, so Courtly bred
As to imploy the utmost of my Rents
In paying Tailors for phantastick Roabes;
Or rather then be second in the fashion,
Eate out my Officers and my Revenues
With grating usury; my back shall not
Be the base on which your soothing Citizen
Erects his Summer-houses; nor on the other side
Will I be so penuriously wise,
As to make money (that's my slave) my Idoll,
Which yet to wrong, merits as much reproof,
As to abuse our servant.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Yet with your pardon
I thinke you want the Crown of all contentment.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: In what good Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In a worthy husband.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: — It is strange the galley-slave should praise
His Oare, or stroakes; or you, that have made shipwracke
Of all delight upon this Rock cal'd marriage,
Should sing Encomions o't.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, though one fall
From his horse and breake his neck, will you
Conclude from that it is unfit to ride?
Or must it follow, because Orleance
My Lord's pleased to make his passionate triall
Of my suspected patience, that my brother,
(Were he not so, I might say, worthy Amiens)
Will imitate his ills, that cannot fancy
What's truely Noble in him?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I must grant
There's as much worth in him as can be lookt for
From a young Lord, but not enough to make
Me change my golden liberty and consent
To be a servant to it, as wives are
To the Imperious humors of their Lords:
Me thinks I'm well, I rise and goe to bed
When I thinke fit, eate what my appetite
Desires without controle, my servants study
Is my contentment, and to make me merry
Their farthest ayms; my sleeps are enquired after,
My rising up saluted with respect:
Command and liberty now waite upon
My Virgin state; what would I more? change all,
And for a husband? no; these freedomes die,
In which they live with my Virginity;
Tis in their choice that's rich to be a wife,
But not being yoakt to chuse the single life.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How like you the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I like the ayre of it well Madam, and the rather because as on Irish Timber your Spiders will not make his web, so for ought I see yet your Cheater, Pander, and Informer being in their dispositions too foggy for this piercing climate, shun it, and choose rather to walk in mists in the City.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who did you serve first boy?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: A rich Merchants widdow, and was by her preferred to a young Court-lady.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: And what difference found you in their service?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Very much: for looke how much my old City Madam gave to her-young visitants, so much my Lady received for her hoary Court-servants.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: And what made you to leave her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My father (Madam) had a desire to have me a tale-man, took me from thence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Well, I perceive you inherit the wag, from your father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Doves beget Doves; and Eagles, Eagles, Madam: A Citizen here, tho left never so rich, seldome at the best proves a Gentleman: the sonne of an Advocate, tho dub'd like his father, will shew a relish of his discent, and the fathers thriving practice, as I have heard: she that of a Chambermayd is metamorphosed into a Madam, will yet remember how oft her daughter by her mother ventured to lie upon the rushes before she could get in that which makes many Ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: But what think you of your late Master?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Oh Madam— Sigh.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why doe you sigh? you are sorry that you left him,
He made a wanton of you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not for that:
Or if he did, for that my youth must love him.
Oh pardon me, if I say liberty
Is bondage, if compared with his kind service;
And but to have power now to speake his worth
To its desert; I should be well content
To be an old man when his praise were ended:
And yet, if at this instant you were pleased,
I should begin, the livery of age
Would take his lodging upon this head
Ere I should bring it to a period.
In briefe he is a man (for God forbid
That I should ever live to say he was
Of such a shape as would make one beloved,
That never had good thought;) and to his body
He hath a mind of such a constant temper
In which vertues throng to have a room:
Yet 'gainst this noble Gentleman, this Montague,
For in that name I comprehend all goodnesse,
Wrong, and the wrested law, false witnesses,
And envy sent from hell, have rose in Armes,
And tho not pierced, battered his honourd shield.
What shall I say? I hope you will forgive me,
That if you were but pleas'd to love,
I know no Juno worthy such a Jove.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis well yet that I have the second place
In your affection: From whence?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: From the Lord Amiens, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis welcome, though it beare his usual language:
I thought so much, his love-suit speake his health.
What's he that brought it?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: A Gentleman of good ranke, it seems.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Receiving entertainment in your house
Sorting with his degree.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: He waites your Ladiships pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He shall not waite long:
Ile leave you for a while; nay stay you boy,
Attend the Lady. Exeunt Lam. Charl.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Would I might live once
To waite on my poore Master.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: That's a good boy:
This thankfulnesse looks lovely on thy forehead,
And in it, as a book, me thinks I read
Instructions for my selfe, that am his debtor,
And wo'd do much that I might be so happy
To repaire that which to our griefe is ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It were a worke a King might glory in,
If he saw with my eyes: If you please Madam,
For sure to me you seem to me unapt to walke,
To sit, although the churlish Birds deny
To give us musicke in this grove, where they
Are prodigall to others: Ile strain my voyce
For a sad Song, the place is safe and private.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Twas my desire; begin good Viramour.

div.stage: Musick a Song, at the end of it enter Montague fainting, his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: What's he Viramour?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: A goodly personage.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Am I yet safe? or is my flight a dream?
My wounds and hunger tell me that I wake:
Whither have my feares borne me? no matter where,
Who hath no place to goe to, cannot erre:
What shall I doe? cunning calamity
That others grosse wits uses to refine,
When I most need it duls the edge of mine.

sp.speaker: L Orl.
sp.l: Is not this Montagues voyce?

sp.speaker: Vir
sp.l: My Masters? fie.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What sound was that, pish,
Feare makes the wretch think every leafe oth' Jury:
What course to live, beg? better men have done it,
But in another kind: steale? Alexander
Though stiled a Conquerour, was a proud thiefe
Though he robd with an Army; fie how idle
These meditations are: though thou art worse
Then sorrows tongue can speak thee, thou art still
Or shouldst be, honest Montague.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Tis too true.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Tis he: what villaines hands did this? oh that my flesh
Were Balme; in faith sir, I would plucke it off
As readily as this; pray you accept
My will to doe you service: I have heard
The Mouse once sav'd the Lyon in his need,
As the poore Scarab spild the Eagles seed.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: How do you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As a forsaken man.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Do not say so, take comfort,
For your misfortunes have been kind in this,
To cast you on a hospitable shoare,
Where dwels a Lady—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: She to whom, good Master,
You prefer'd me.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In whose house, whatsoere
Your dangers are, Ile undertake your safety.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I feare that I am pursued, and doubt that I
In my defence have kild an Officer.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Is that all? there's no law under the Sunne
But will I hope confesse, one drop of blood
Shed from this arme is recompence enough
Though you had cut the throats of all the Catchpoles
In France, nay in the world.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would be loth
To be a burthen, or feed like a drone
On the industrious labour of a Bee,
And baser far I hold it to owe for
The bread I eate, what's not in me to pay;
Then since my full fortunes are declined,
To their low ebb Ile fashion my high mind.
It was no shame to Hecuba to serve
When Troy was fired: ift be in your power
To be a means to make her entertainment,
And far from that I was; but to supply
My want with habit fit for him that serves,
I shall owe much to you.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Leave that care to me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Good sir, leaue on my shoulder; helpe good Madam. oh that I were a horse for halfe an houre, that I might carry you home on my backe: I hope you wil love me still?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou dost deserve it boy, that I should live
To be thus troublesome.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Good sir, tis none.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Trouble most willingly; I would be changd
Like Apuleius, weare his Asses eares,
Provided I might still this burthen beare.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Tis a kind boy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I finde true proofe of it. Exeunt:

div.stage: Enter Amiens and Longeville with a Paper.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You'l carry it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: As I live although my packet were like Bellerophons, what have you seen in me or my behaviour since your favours so plentifully showed upon my wants, that may beget distrust of my performance?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry, if I entertained
But the least scruple of your love, or courage,
I would make of one which my state
Should do me right in this, nor can you blame me
If in a matter of such consequence
I am so importunate.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Good my Lord tell me, prevent your further conjurations
To rayse my spirit, I know this is a challenge
To be delivered unto Orleance hand,
And that my undertaking ends not there,
But I must be your second, and in that
Not alone search your enemy, measure weapons,
But stand in all your hazzards, as our blouds
Ran in the self same veines, in which if I
Better not your opinion, as a limbe
That's putrifyed and uselesse, cut me off,
And underneath the Gallons bury it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: At full you understand me, and in this
Binde me and what's mine to you and yours,
I wil not so much wrong you as to adde
One sylable more, let it suffice I leave
My honor to your guard: and in that prove
You hold the first place in my heart and love. Exit Ami.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The first place in a Lords affection? very good; and how long doth that last? perhaps the changing of some three shirts in the Tennis Court; wel it were very necessary that an order were taken (if it were possible,) that younger brother, might have more wit, or more money: for now how ever the foole hath long bin put upon him that inherits his revenew hath brought him a spunge, and wip't off the imputation, and for the understanding of the younger, let him get as much rhetorick as he can to grace his language.
They wil see he shall have glosse little enough to set out his barck; stand Dubois look about all safe.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Approach not neer me but with reverence
Lawrell and adorations, I have done more then deserve a 100 thanks.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: With this hand only aided by this brain,
Without an Orpheus Harp redeem'd from hels
Three headed Porter, our Euridice.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Nay prithee speak sence, this is like the stale braggart in a Play.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Then in plaine Prose thus, and with as little action as thou canst desire, the three headed Porter, were three unexorable Catch-poles out of whose jawes without the help of Orpheus Harp, baite or bribe, for those too stringes, makes the Musique that mollifies those flinty furies, I rescued our Euridice, I meane my old Master Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And is this all, a poor rescue, I thought thou hadst reverst the judgement for his overthrow, in his sute, or wrought upon his adversary Orleance, taken the shape of a Ghost, frighted his mind into distraction, and for the appeasing of his conscience forc'd him to make restitution of Montagues Lands, or such like rescued; slight I would have hired Crohieture for two Cardekues to have done so much with his whip.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: You wood sir, and yet tis more then three on their foot-cloathes durst do for a sworne Brother, in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Besides what proofs of it, for ought I know this may be a trick, I had rather have him a Prisoner, where I might visit him, and do him service, then not at all, or I know not where.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Well sir, the end wil shew it, what's that a challenge?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, wher's Orleance? though we fight in jest he must meet with Amiens in earnest,— fall off, we are discovered; my horse garcon ha'.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Were it not in a house and in his presence,
To whom I owe all duty—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What would it do? prate as it do's? but be as far from stricking as he that owes it Orleans.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I think thou art his Porter,
Set here to answer creditors, that his Lordship
Is not within or takes the diet. I am sent,
And wil grow here untill I have an answer,
Not to demand a debt of money, but
To call him to a strict account for wrong
Done to the honors of a Gentleman,
Which nothing but his heart-bloud shall wash off.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Shall I hear this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And more, that if I may not
Have accesse to him, I will six this here
To his disgrace and thine.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And thy life with it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then have the coppies of it pasted on posts,
Like Phamplet titles that sue to be sold;
Have his disgrace talk for Tobacco shops,
His picture bafful'd.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: All respect away, wer't in a Church— draw both

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the book I pray with.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Forbear upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What are you rous'd? I hope your Lordship can read (though he staine not his birth with scholler-ship) doth it not please you now? if you are a right Mounsier, muster up the rest of your attendance, which is a page, a cook, a pander, coach-man, and a foot man, in these dayes a great Lords traine, pretending I am unworthy to bring you a challenge, in stead of answering it, have me kik't.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: If he does thou deserv'st it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare you all to touch me, I'le not stand still,
What answer you?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That thou hast done to Amience
The office of a faithfull friend which I
Would cherish in thee were he not my foe,
How ever since on honorable tearmes
He cals me forth, say I will meet with him,
And by Dubois ere Sun-set make him know
The time and place, my swords length, and what ever
Scruple of circumstance he can expect.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This answer comes unlookt for, far you well,
Finding your temper thus, wood I had sayd lesse. Exit.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now Comes thy love to the test.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: My Lord 'twill hold,
And in all dangers prove it selfe true gold. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I wil acquaint my Lady with your comming.
Please you repose your selves here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ther's a tester, nay now I am a woer I must be bountifull.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: If you would have two three-pences for it sir, To give some of your kindred as you ride, I'le see if I can get them; we use not (tho Servants) to take Bribes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Then thou art unfit, to be in office either in Court or City.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Indeed corruption is a Tree whose branches are of an unmeasurable length they spread every where, and the dew that drops from thence have infected some chayres and stooles of authority.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Ah Captaine, lay not all the fault upon Officers
you know you can shark though you be out of action, witnesse Montague.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Hang him, hee's safe enough; you had a hand in it to and have gained by him; but I wonder you Citizens that keep so many bookes, and take such strict accounts for every farthing due to you from others, reserve not so much as a memorandum for the curtesies you receive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Would you have a Citizen book those? thankfulnes is a thing we are not sworn to in our indentures: you may as well urge conscience.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Talke no more of such vanities.
