Montague is irrecoverably sunk, I would we had twenty more to send after him; the Snake that would be a Dragon and have wings must eate; and what imployes that but this, that in this Canniball age he that would have the sute of wealth must not care— whom he feeds on? and as I have heard no flesh battens better, then that of a profest friend; and he that would mount to honour must not make dainty to use the head of his mother, back of his father, or neck of his brother, for ladders to his preferment; for but observe, and you shall finde for the most part cunning villany sit at a feast as principall guest, and Innocent honesty waite as a contemn'd servant with a trencher.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: The Ladies.

div.stage: Enter Mountague bare-headed, Lamira, Lady Orleance, Charlo, Veramour, salute.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Do yee smell nothing?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The carrion of knaves is very strong in my nostrels.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: We came to admire, and finde fame was a niggard
Which we thought prodigall in our report
Before we saw you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tush sir, this Courtship's old.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Ile fight for thee sweet wench,
This is my tongue and woes for me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good man of War,
Hands of; if you take me it must be by siege,
Not by an onset; and for your valour, I
Think that I have deserved few enemies,
And therefore need it not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou needst nothing sweet Lady, but an obsequious husband, and where wilt thou finde him, if not in the City: we are true Moscovits to our Wives, and are never better pleased, then when they use us as slaves, bridle and saddle us; have me, thou shalt command all my wealth as thine own, thou shalt sit like a Queen in my ware house; And my factors at the returne with my ships shall pay thee tribute of all the rarities of the earth; thou shalt wear gold, feed on delicates, the first peascods-strauberies, grapes, cherries shall—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be mine; I apprehend what you would say,
Those dainties which the City payes so dear for,
The Country yeilds for nothing, and as early;
And credit me your far fet viandes please not
My appetite better then those that are neer hand.
Then for your promis'd service and subjection
To all my humors, when I am your wife,
Which as it seemes is frequent in the City,
I cannot finde what pleasure they receive
In using there fond husbands like their Maydes;
But of this more hereafter; I accept
Your proffer kindly, and yours; my house stands open
To entertain you; take your pleasure in it,
And ease after your journey.

sp.speaker: La. Orl.
sp.p: Do you note the boldnesse of the fellowes?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Alas Madam, a virgin must in this be like a lawyer,
And as he takes all fees, shee must hear all suitors; the
One for gaine, the other for her mirth; stay with the
Gentlemen, wee'l to the Orchards. Exeunt Lamira, La. Orle. Veram. Charl.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: — what art thou?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: An honest man, though poor;
And look they like to monsters, are they so rare?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Rose from the dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you heare Mounsier Serviture, didst thou never heare of one Montague a prodigall gull, that lives about Paris?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: One that after the losse of his maine estate in a
Law sute, bought an Office in the Court.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And should have letters of Mart, to have the Spanish treasure as it came from the Indies; were not thou and he twins? put of thy hat, let me see thy forehead.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Though you take priviledge to use your tongues,
I pray you hold your fingers,
'Twas your base cozenage made me as I am,
And were you some where else I would take off
This proud filme from your eyes, that will not tell you,
Know I am Montague.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I will observe this better.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: And art thou he? I wil do thee grace; give me thy hand; I am glad thou hast taken so good a course; serve God and please thy Mistris; if I prove to be thy Master as I am very likely, I will do for thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith the fellow's well made for a servingman, and will no doubt carry a chyne of Beefe with good grace.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Prithee be carefull of me in my chamber, I will remember thee at my departure.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All this I can indure under this roof,
And so much owe I her, whose now I am,
That no wrong shall incense me to molest
Her quiet house; while you continue here,
I will not be ashamed to do you service
More then to her, because such is her pleasure.
But you that have broke thrice, and foureteen times
Compounded for two shillings in the pound,
Know I dare kick you in your shop; do ye hear?
If ever I see Paris, though an army
Of musty Murrions, rusty brown bils and clubs,
Stand for your guard— I have heard of your tricks,
And you that smell of Amber at my charge,
And triumph in your cheat; well I may live
To meet thee, be it among a troop of such
That are upon the faire face of the Court
Like running ulcers, and before thy whore
Trampell upon thee.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: This a language for a livery? take heed, I am a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A Gox-comb are you not? that thou and I
To give proof, which of us dares most, were now
In mid'st of a rough Sea, upon a piece
Of a split ship, where only one might ride, Exit Lamira from the Arras.
I would— but foolish anger makes me talke
Like a Player.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed you act a part
Doth ill become you my servant; is this your duty?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I crave your pardon, and wil hereafter be more circumspect.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Oh the power of a Womans tongue! it had
done more then we three with our swords durst undertake: put a madde man to silence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why Sirra these are none of your comrades
To drink with in the celler; one of them
For ought you know may live to be your Master.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Ther's some comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Here's choyce of three, a wealthy Merchant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hem, shee's taken, she hath spy'd my good Calf,
And many Ladies chuse their husbands by that.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A Courtier that's in grace, a valiant Captaine,
And are these mates for you? away be gon.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I humbly pray you will be pleased to pardon,
And to give satisfaction to you Madam.
(Although I break my heart) I will confesse
That I have wrong'd them too, and make submission.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: No I'le spare that; goe bid the Cook haste Supper. Exit Mont.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Oh brave Lady thou art worthy to have servants, to be commandresse of a Family, that knowst how to use and govern it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You shall have many Mistresses that will so mistake as to take their horse keepers, and footemen insteed of their Husbands, thou art none of those.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But she that can make distinction of men, and knowes when she hath gallants, and fellowes of rank and quality in her house—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Gallants indeed, if it be the Gallants fashion
To triumph in the miseries of a man,
Of which they are the cause: one that transcends
(In spight of all that fortune hath, or can be done)
A million of such things as you, my doores
Stand open to receive all such as wear
The shape of Gentlemen, and my gentlier nature
(I might say weaker) weighes not the expence
Of entertainment; think you I'le forget yet
What's due unto my selfe? do not I know,
That you have dealt with poor Montague, but like
Needy Commanders, cheating Citizens,
And perjured Courtiers? I am much mov'd, else use not
To say so much, if you will bear your selves
As fits such you would make me think you are,
You may stay; if not the way lies before you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What think you of this Captaine?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: That this is a baudy house, with Pinacles and Turrets, in which this disguised Montague goes to rut grat is, and that this is a landed pandresse, and makes her house a brothell for charity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Come, that's no miracle; but from whence derive you the supposition?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Observe but the circumstance; you all know that in the height of Montagues prosperity, hee did affect and had his love return'd by this Lady Orleans; since her divorcement, and his decay of estate, it is knowne, they have met not so much as his boy is wanting; and that this can be any thing else then a meer plot for their night work, is above my imagination to conceive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay it carries probability, let us observe it better, but yet with such caution as our prying be not discovered: here's all things to be had without cost, and therefore good staying here.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Nay that's true, I would we might woe her twenty years like Penelopes sutors; come Laverdine.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I follow instantly, yonder he is.
The thought of this Boy hath much coold my affection to his Lady, and by all conjectures, this is a disguised whore; I will try if I can search this Mine. Page—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Thou art a pritty Boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: And you a brave man: now I am out of your debt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Nay prithy stay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I am in haste sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By the faith of a Courtyer.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Take heed what you say, you have taken a strange Oath.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I have not seene a youth that hath pleased me better, I would thou could'st like me, so far as to leave thy Lady and waite on me, I would maintaine thee in the bravest Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Though you took them up on trust, or bought 'em at the brokers.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or any way: then thy imployments should bee so neate and cleanly, thou shouldst not touch a payre of Pantables in a Moneth, and thy lodging—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Should be in a brothell.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: No, but in mine armes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: That my be the circle of a Baudy house, or worse.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I meane thou shouldest lie with me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Lie with you? I had rather lie with my Ladies Monkey; 'twas never a good World since our French Lords learned of the Neopolitans; to make their Pages their Bed-fellowes, doth more hurt to the Suburbe Ladies then tweenty dead Vacations; Tis Supper time sir. Exit Veram.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I thought so, I know by that 'tis a Woman, for because peradventure she hath made tryall of the Monkey, she preferrs him before me, as one unknown; well these are standing Creatures, and have strange desires; And men must use strange meanes to quench strange fires.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Montague, alone, in meane habit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Now Montague, who discerns thy spirit now?
Thy breeding or thy bloud? here's a poor cloud
Ecclipseth all thy splendor; who can reade
In thy pale face, dead eye, or lenten shute,
The liberty thy ever giving hand
Hath bought for others, manacling it selfe
In gives of parchment indissoluble?
The greatest hearted man supplyed with meanes,
Nobility of birth and gentlest parts,
I though the right hand of his Soveraigne,
If vertue quit her seat in his high soule,
Glitters but like a Pallace set on fire,
Whose glory whilst it shines, but ruins him,
And his bright show each houre to ashes tending
Shall at the last be rak't up like a sparkle,
Unlesse mens lives and fortunes feede the flame.
Not for my own wants though blame I my Stars,
But suffering others to cast love on me,
When I can neither take nor thankfull be.
My Ladies woman, faire and vertuous
Young as the present moneth, sollicits me
For love and marriage now being nothing worth—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh Master, I have sought you a long hour,
Good faith, I never joyd out of your sight;
For Gods sake sir be merry, or else beare
The Buffets of your fortunes with more scorn;
Do but begin to raile, teach me the way,
And Ile sit down and help your anger forth:
I have known you weare a suit full worth a Lordship,
Give to a man whose need nere frighted you
From calling of him friend, five hundred Crowns
Ere sleep had left your sences to consider
Your own important present uses; yet
Since I have seen you with a trencher waite,
Voide of all scorne, therefore Ile waite on you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Would God thou wert lesse honest.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Would to God you were lesse worthy: I am even w'ee sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Is not thy Master strangely fallen, when thou
Servest for no wages, but for charity?
Thou dost surcharge me with thy plenteous love:
The goodnesse of thy vertue shown to me,
More opens still my disability
To quit thy pains: Credit me loving boy,
A free and honest nature may be opprest,
Tir'd with curtesies from a liberall spirit,
When they exceed his means of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But tis a due in him that to that end
Extends his love or duty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Little world
Of vertue, why dost love and follow me?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I will follow you through all Countries,
Ile run (fast as I can) by your horse side,
Ile hold your stirrop when you doe alight,
And without grudging waite till you returne:
Ile quit offerd meanes, and expose my selfe
To cold and hunger still to be with you;
Fearlesse Ile travell through a wildernesse,
And when you are weary, I will lay me down
That in my bosome you may rest your head,
Where whilst you sleep, Ile watch that no wild beast
Shall hurt or trouble you: and thus we'l breed a story
To make every hearer weep,
When they discourse our fortunes and our loves.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Oh what a scoffe might men of Wormes make,
If they did know this boy? but my desire
Is that thou wouldest not (as thou usest still
When like a servant I 'mong servants sit)
Waite on my Trencher, fill my cups with wine:
Why shouldst thou doe this boy? prethee consider,
I am not what I was.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Curst be the day when I forget that Montague was my Lord, or not remember him my Master still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Rather curse me, with whom thy youth hath spent
So many houres, and yet untaught to live
By any worldly qualitie.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed you never taught me how to handle Cards
To cheat and coz in men with oathes and lies;
Those are the wordly qualities to live:
Some of our Scarlet Gallants teach their boyes
These worldly qualities.
Since stumbling fortune then leaves vertue thus
Let me leave fortune, ere be vicious.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Oh lad, thy love will kill me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: In truth, I think in conscience I shall die for you:
Good Master weep not, doe you want aught sir?
Will you have any money? here's some Silver;
And here's a little Gold, 'twill serve to play,
And put more troublesome thoughts out of your mind:
I pray sir take it, Ile get more with singing.
And then Ile bring it you; my Lady ga't me,
And— it was not covetousnesse,
But I forgot to tell you sooner on't.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Alasse boy, thou art not bound to tell it me,
And lesse to give it, buy thee Scarfes and Garters,
And when I have money, I will give thee a Sword:
Nature made thee a beauteous Cabinet
To lock up all the godnesse of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I have lost my voyce with the very sight of this Gentlewoman: good sir steale away, you were wont to be a curious avoyder of womens company.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy, thou darst trust me any where, darst thou not?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I had rather trust you by a roaring Lyon, then a ravening woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why truly she devoures more mans flesh—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I, But she roares not boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No sir, why she is never silent but when her mouth is full.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Mounsier Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My sweet fellow, since you please to call me so.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ah my conscience she would be pleased well enough to call you bedfellow: oh Master, do not hold her by the hand so: a woman is a lyme-bush, that catcheth all she toucheth.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I do most dangerously suspect this boy to be a wench; art thou not one? come hither, let me feele thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Why dost thou pull off thy glove?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, to feele whether you be a boy, or no.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie boy, goe too, Ile not looke your head, nor combe your locks any more, if you talke thus.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, Ile sing to you no more then.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie upon't, how sad you are? a young Gentleman that was the very Sunne of France.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: But I am in the eclipse now.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Suffer himselfe to be over-run with a Lethargy of melancholy and discontent! rouze up thy spirit, man, and shake it off:
sp.l: A Noble soule is like a ship at Sea,
That sleepes at Anchor when the Ocean's calme;
But when she rages, and the wind blows high,
He cuts his way with skill and Majesty.
sp.p: I would turn a foole, or Poet, or any thing, or marry, to make you merry; prethee let's walke: good Veramour leave thy Master and me, I have earnest businesse with him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Pray doe you leave my Master, and me; we were very merry before you came, he does not covet womens companie.
sp.l: What have you to do with him? come sir will you goe?
And Ile sing to you again:
sp.p: I'faith his mind is stronger then to credit womens vows, and too pure to be capable of their loves.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: The boy is jealous; sweet lad leave us; my Lady call'd for you I sweare: that's a good child, there's a piece of Gold for thee, go buy a Feather.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
There's two pieces for you, do you goe and buy one, or what you will, or nothing so you goe. Nay then I see you would have me go sir; why, 'faith I will; now I perceive you love her better then you doe me; but
God blesse you whatever you do, or intend; I know you are a very honest man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Still shall I woe thee, whilst thy eares reply
I cannot, or I will not marry thee?
Why hast thou drawn the blood out of my cheekes,
And given a quicker motion to my heart?
Oh thou hast bred a fever in my veines
Call'd love, which no Physitian can cure;
Have mercy on a maid whose simple youth—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How your example fairest teacheth me
A ceremonious Idolatry! kneels.
By all the joy of love I love thee better
Then I or any man can tell another;
And will expresse the mercy which thou crav'st,
I will forbeare to marry thee: consider
Thou art natures heire in feature, and thy parents
In faire inheritances; rise with these thoughts,
And look on me; but with a womans eye,
A decayd fellow, voyd of means and spirit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Of spirit?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes, could I tamely live,
Forget my fathers blood, waite and make legs,
Staine my best breeches, with the servile drops
That fall from others draughts:

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: This vizard wherewith thou wouldst hide thy spirit
Is perspective, to shew it plainlier.
This under-value of thy life is but
Because I should not buy thee; what more speaks
Greatnesse of man, then valiant patience,
That shrinks not under his fates strongest strokes?
These Roman deaths, as falling on a Sword,
Opening of veines, with poyson quenching thirst,
(Which we erroneously doe stile the deeds
Of the heroicke and magnanimous man)
Was dead-eyd cowardise, and white cheeke feare,
Who doubting tyranny, and fainting under
Fortunes false Lottery, desperately runne
To death for dread of death; that soules most stout,
That bearing all mischance, dares last it out;
Will you performe your word, and marry me,
When I shall call you to't?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Who's this alights here?

sp.speaker: Long,
sp.p: With leave faire creature, are you the Lady Mistris of the house?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Her servant sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I pray then favour me, to inform your Lady, and
Duke Orleans wife,
A businesse of emport awaites 'em here,
And craves for speedy answer.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Are you in post sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, I am in Satin Lady; I would you would be in post.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I will returne. Sweet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Honest friend, doe you belong to the house?
I pray be covered.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I doe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Ha, dreamst thou Longaville? sure tis not he: sir
I should know you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So should I you, but that I am asham'd.
But though thou knowst me, prethee Longaville,
Mock not my poverty, pray remember your selfe;
Showes it not strangely for thy cloathes to stand
Without a hat to mine? mocke me no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: She— embroyder me all over sir,
If ever I began to mocke you yet.
The— on me, why should I weare Velvet
And Silver Lace,— I will teare it off.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why mad-man?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Put on my Hat? yes, when I am hangd I will:
— I could break my head
For holding eyes that knew not you at first:
But time and fortune run your courses with him,
He'l laugh and storm you, when you shew most hate.

div.stage: Enter Lamira, Orleans Lady, Laverdine, La Poope, Malycorne, Veramour, Charlot:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You're a fair Mounsier.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Doe you mocke me Lady?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your businesse sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Regard your selfe good Mounsier Longueville.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are too negligent of your selfe and place,
Cover your head sweet Mounsier.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Mistake me not faire Ladies,
Tis not to you, nor you, that I stand bare.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Nay sweet deere Mounsier, let it not be to us then.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: — a complement.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And— of manners.
Pray hide your head, your gallants use to do't.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you your foreheads, why you needful accessary rascals,
That cannot live without your mutuall knaveries,
More then a Bawd, a Pandor, or a Whore
From one another; how dare you suspect
That I stand bare to you? what make you here?
Shift your house Lady of 'em, for I know 'em,
They come to steale Napkins, and your Spoons;
Look to your Silver-bodkin, (Gentlewoman)
Tis a dead utensil, and Page 'ware your pockets;
My reverence is unto this man, my master,
Whom you with protestations, and oaths
As high as Heaven, as deep as hell, which would
Deceive the wisest man of honest nature,
Have cozned and abus'd; but I may meet you,
And beate you one with t'other.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace, no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am something thicke of hearing; what said he?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I heare him, but regard him not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, I am never angry fasting.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My love keeps back my duty, noblest Lady;
If husband or brother merit love from you,
Prevent their dangers, this houre brings to triall
Their hereto sleeping hates; by this time each
Within a yerd is of the others heart,
And met to prove their causes and their spirits
With their impartiall Swords points; haste and save,
Or never meet them more but at the grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh my distracted heart, that my wrackt honour Should for a brothers, or a husbands life, through thy undoing die.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Amiens engagd; if he miscarry all my hopes and joys,
I now confesse it loudly, are undone:
Caroch, and haste, one minute may betray
A life more worth then all time can repay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Hump: Mounsier Laverdine pursues this boy extreamly. Captaine what will you doe?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Any thing but follow to this Sea-service; I am a Sea-captaine you know, and to offer to part 'em, without we could do't like water-men with long staves, a quarter of a mile off, might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then let's retire and pray for 'em, I am resolv'd to stop your intent; abus'd more then we have been we cannot be, without they fall to flat beating o'us.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: And that were unkindly done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: — but you are the troublesomest Asse that ere I met with; retire, you smel like a womans chamber, that's newly up, before she have pinsht her vapours in with her cloathes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I will haunt thee like thy Grandames ghost, thou shalt never rest for me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Well, I perceive tis vaine to conceale a secret from you: believe it sir, indeed I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why la; I knew't, this Propheticall tongue of mine never faild me; my mother was halfe a witch, never any thing that she forespake, but came to passe: a woman? how happy am I? now we may lawfully come together without feare of hanging; Sweet wench, be gracious, in honourable sort I woe, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Faith the truth is I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: See, see.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But durst not open it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: — I think so.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But briefly, when you bring it to the test, if there be not one Gentleman in this house, wil challenge more interest in me, then you can, I am at your disposure.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Oh Fortunatus, I envie thee not
For cap, or pouch, this day Ile prove my Fortune,
In which your Lady doth elect her husband,
Who will be Amiens, 'twill save my wedding dinner,
Povera, La-poop and Malicorne: if all faile,
I will turne Citizen, a beauteous wife
Is the horn-booke to the richest Tradesmans life.

div.stage: Enter Duboys, Orleans, Longueville, Amiens, two Lacques, a Page wish two Pistols.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here's a good even piece of ground my Lords:
Will you fix here?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes any where; Lacquey, take off my spurs;
Upon a bridge, a raile but my Swords bredth, upon a battlement,
Ile fight this quarrell.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: O' the ropes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Upon a line.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: So all our Countrie Duels are carried, like a fire-worke on a thred.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Go now stay with the horses, and doe you heare
Upon your lives, till some of us come to you,
Dare not to looke this way.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Except you see strangers or others that by chance or purpose are like to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then give warning.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Who takes a Sword? the advantage is so small,
As he that doubts hath the free leave to choose.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Come give me any, and search me; tis not
The ground, weapon, or seconds that can make
Oddes in those fatall trials: but the cause.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Most true, and but it is no time to wish
When men are come to do, I would desire
The cause 'twixt us were other then it is;
But where the right is, there prevaile our Swords.
And if my sister have outliv'd her honour,
I doe not pray I may outlive her shame.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Your sister Amiens, is a whore, at once.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You oft have spoke that sence to me before,
But never in this language Orleance;
And when yov spoke it faire, and first, I told you
That it was possible you might be abus'd:
But now, since you forget your manners, you shall finde,
If I transgresse my custome, you doe lie,
And are a villaine, which I had rather yet
My Sword had prov'd, then I been forc'd to speake:
Nay give us leave, and since you stand so haughtily
And highly on your cause, let you and I,
Without engaging these two Gentlemen, singly determine it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, you'l pardon us.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I trust your Lordships may not doe us that affront.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We kisse your Lordships hand, and come to serve you here with Swords.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, we understand our selves.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We have had the honour to be call'd unto the businesse, and we must not now quit it on terms.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not terms of reason?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, no reason for the quitting of our calling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: True if I be call'd to't I must aske no reason.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nor heare none neither, which is lesse:
It is a favour if my throat be cut,
Your Lordship does me; which I never can,
sp.stage: A noise within, crying down with their Swords.
sp.l: Nor must have hope how to requite: what noise,
What cry is that my Lord upon your guard?
Some treachery is a foot.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O here they are:
My Lord (deare Lady helpe me) helpe me all;
I have so woefull interest in both,
I know not which to feare for most: and yet
I must prefer my Lord. Deare brother,
You are too understanding, and too Noble
To be offended, when I know my duty,
Though scarce my teares will let me so to do it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Out loathed strumpet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my dearest Lord,
If words could on me cast the name of whore,
I then were worthy to be loath'd; but know,
Your unkindnesse cannot make me wicked;
And therefore should lesse use that power upon me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Was this your art to have these actors come,
To make this interlude? withdraw, cold man,
And if thy spirit be not frozen up,
Give me one stroke yet at thee for my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Thou shalt have stroakes, and stroakes, thou glorious man,
Till thou breathst thinner ayre then that thou talkest.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord Count Amiens.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Princely husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Whore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You wrong her impudent Lord; O that I had the bulke
Of those dull men; look how they stand, and no man
Will revenge an innocent Lady.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: You hinder it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I would hinder you; is there none else to kill him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Kill him Madam? have you learn'd that bad Language? O repent,
And be the motive, rather both kill me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then die my infamy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Hold bloody man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Art thou their Basiliske?

sp.speaker: Mont:
sp.p: To strike thee dead, but that thy fate deserves some weightier hand.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O here's a plot; you bring your champions with you; the adultresse with the adulterer: Out howling—

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Are you her Graces countenance Lady, the
receiver to the poore vicious couple.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Sweet rascall, didst not thou tell me, false fellow,
This Montague, here was murdered?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I did so; but he was falser, and a worthlesse Lord,
Like thy foule selfe, that would have had it so.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Orleance tis true, and shall be prov'd upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Thy malice Duke, and this thy wicked nature, are all as visible as thou; but I borne to contemne thy iniuries, doe know, that though thy greatnesse may corrupt a Jury, and make a Judge afraid, and carry out a world of devils with thy title: yet thou art not quiet at home, thou bearest about thee that, that doth charge thee, and condemne thee too. The thing that grieves me more, and doth indeed displease me, is, to thinke that so much basenesse stands here to have encountered so much honour: Pardon me my Lord what late my passion spake, when you provok'd my innocence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes doe, O flattery becomes him better then the sute he weares; give him a new one Amiens.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Orleance, tis here no time nor place, to jest or raile
Poorely with you, but I will finde a time to
Whisper you forth to this or some fit place,
As shall not hold a second interruption.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I hope your Lordships honour, and your life
Are destined unto higher hazzards; this is of
A meaner arme.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Yes faith, or none.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He is not fit to fall by an honest Sword,
A Prince and lie!

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And slander, and hire men
To publish the false rumours he hath made.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And sticke 'em on his friends, and innocents.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: And practice against their lives after their fames.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In men that are the matter of all leudnesse,
Bands, thieves, and cheaters, it were monstrous.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But in a man of blood, how more conspicuous?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: They doe slander him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hang them, a paire of railing hangbies.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How? stand Orleance; stay, give me my Pistols boy,
Hinder me not, by—
I will kill him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O stay his fury,

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longueville, my friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not for my selfe, my Lord, but for mankind,
And all that have an interest to vertue,
Or title unto innocence.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Why heare me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: For justice sake.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: To punish his wives, your honour, and my Lords wrongs here, whom I must ever call so; for your loves Ile sweare, Ile sacrifice—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longaville, I did not thinke you a murtherer before.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I care not what you thought me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By— If thou attempt
His life, thy own is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Foolish frantick man, the murder will be of us, not him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We could have kild him, but we would not take
The justice out of fates.—
Singe but a haire of him, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No matter, shoot.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Villaine.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: My Lord, your sister is slaine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Biancha?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O haplesse and most wretched chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Standst thou looking upon the mischief thou hast made
Thou Godlesse man, feeding thy blood-shot eyes
With the red spectacle, and art not turn'd to stone
With horrour? hence and take the wings of thy blacke
Infamy, to carry thee beyond the shoot of looks,
Or sound of curses, which will pursue thee still:
Thou hast out-fled all but thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O wish it off again, for I am crack'd
Under the burden, and my heart will breake.
How heavy guilt is, when men come to feele
If you could know the mountaine I sustaine
With horror, you would each take off your part,
And more, to ease me: I cannot stand,
Forgive where I have wrong'd I pray.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Looke to him Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My Lords and Gentlemen, the Lady is well, but for feare,
Unlesse that have shot her;
I have the worst on't, that needs would venture
Upon a tricke had like to ha' cost my guts:
Look to her, she'l be well, it was but Powder
I chargd with, thinking that a guilty man
Would have been frighted sooner; but I am glad
He's come at last.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How is Byancha? well?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Lives she? see sister, doth she breath?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, thinke you I can breath,
That am restored to the hatefull sense
Of feeling in me my deare husbands death?
O no, I live not; life was that I left;
And what you have cal'd me to, is death indeed;
I cannot weep so fast as he doth bleed.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha my husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I cannot speake whether my joy or shame
Be greater, but I thank the Heavens for both.
O look not black upon me, all my friends,
To whom I will be reconciled, or grow unto
This earth, till I have weept a trench
That shall be great enough to be my grave,
And I will think them too most manly teares,
If they do move your pities: it is true,
Man should do nothing that he should repent;
But if he have, and say that he is sorry,
It is a worse fault if he be not truly.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Lord, such sorrow cannot be suspected:
Here take your honoured wife, and joyn your hands.
— she hath married you again:
And Gentlemen, I do invite you all,
This night to take my house, where on the morrow,
To heighten more the reconciling feast,
Ile make my selfe a husband and a guest. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well now I am sure you are mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I am sure I am glad
I have one to own then; you'l finde me honest
As these daies go, enough; poore without question,
Which beggars hold a vertue; give me meat, and I
Shall do my worke, else knock my shooes off,
And turn me out again.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have no great cause.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yes thy love to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's as we make our game.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why you repent then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Faith no wors then I am I cannot be;
Much better I expect not: I shall love you,
And when you bid me goe to bed, obey,
Lie still or move, as you shall minister,
Keep a foure-nobles Nag, and a black
Merling, learn to love Ale, and play at two-hand Irish,
And there's then all I aime at.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nay sweet fellow, Ile make it something better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you doe, you'l make me worse:
Now I am poore, and willing to doe wel,
Hold me in that course, of all the Kings creatures,
I hate his coyne, keep me from that, and save me;
For if you chance out of your housewifery
To leave a hundred pound or two, bestow it
In Plum-broth ere I know it, else I take it;
Seeke out a hundred men that want this money,
Share it among 'em, they'l cry noble Montague,
And so I stand again at livery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You have pretty fancies sir, but married once,
This charity will fall home to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would it would, I am afraid my loosenesse
Is yet scarce stopt, though it have nought to worke on
But the meere aire of what I have had.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pretty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I wonder sweet heart why you'l marry me,
I can see nothing in my selfe deserves it,
Unlesse the handsome wearing of a band,
For that's my stocke now, or a paire of garters,
Necessity will not let me loose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I see sir a great deale more, a hansome man, a husband
To make a right good woman truely happy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord, where are my eyes? either you are foolish
As wenches once a yeere are, or far worse,
Extreamly vertuous, can you love a poore man
That relies on cold meat and cast stockings,
One onely suit to his backe, which now is mewing?
But what will be the next coate will pose Tristram.
If I should leavy from my friends a fortune:
I could not raise ten groats to pay the Priest now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ile do that duty; tis not means nor money
Makes me pursue your love; were your mind bankrupt,
I would never love you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace wench, here's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Nay never shrinke i'th wetting, for my presence;
D'ee finde her willing Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Willing Madam?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How dainty you make of it, doe not I know
You two love one another?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Certaine Madam, I thinke ye'ave revelations of these matters:
Your Ladyship cannot tell me when I kist her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But she can, sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But she will not Madam;
For when they talke once, tis like fairy-money,
They get no more close kisses.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art wanton.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: God knows I need not, yet I would be lusty:
But— my provender scarce pricks me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: It shall be mended Montague, I am glad you are grown so merry.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So am I too Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You two will make a pretty hansome consort.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Madam, if my fiddle faile me not.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Your Fiddle? why your Fiddle? I warrant thou meanest madly:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Can you blame me? alasse I am in love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Tis very well sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How thus in love?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are very quick sir: no, I mean thus pleasant.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: — Ever since I was poore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A little wealth would change you then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Lady into another suit, but never more
Into another man: Ile bar that mainly,
The wealth I get henceforward shal be charm'd
For ever hurting me, Ile spend it fasting:
As I live noble Lady there is nothing
I have found directly cures the melancholy,
But want and wedlocke; when I had store of money
I simper'd sometime, and spoke wondrous wise,
But never laught out-right; now I am empty
My heart sounds like a bell, and strikes at both sides.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are finely temper'd Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pardon Lady, if any way my free mirth have offended,
Twas meant to please you: if it prove too sawsie,
Give it a frown, and I am ever silenc'd.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like it passing well; pray follow it:
This is my day of choice, and shall be yours too,
Twere pity to delay ye: call to the Steward,
And tell him tis my pleasure he should give you
500 Crowns: make your selfe hansome Montague,
Let none weare better cloathes, tis for my credit;
But pray be merry still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If I be not, and make a foole of twice as many hundreds,
Clap me in Canvas Lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am strangely glad, I have found the mystery
Of this disguised boy out: I ever trusted
It was a woman, and how happily
I have found it so; and for my selfe, I am sure
One that would offer me a thousand pound now
(And that's a pretty sum to make one stagger)
In ready gols for this concealment, could not
Buy my hope of her, she's a dainty wench,
And such a one I finde, I want extreamly
To bring me into credit: beauty does it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Say we should all meach here, and stay the feast, now what can the worst be? we have plai'd the knaves, that's without question.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: True, and as I take it this is the first truth
We told these ten yeeres, and for any thing
I know may be the last: but grant we are knaves,
Both base and beastly knaves—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Say so then.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: And likewise let it be considered, we have wrongd
And most maliciously, this Gentlewoman,
We cast to stay with, what must we expect now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I there's the point, we would expect good eating.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I know we would, but we may find good beating.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You say true Gentlemen, and by—
Though I love meat as well as any man,
I care not what he be, if a eate a Gods name;
Such crab-sauce to my meat wil turn my pallate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: There's all the hazzard, for the frozen Montague
Has now got spring againe, and warmth in him,
And without doubt dares beat us terribly.
For not to mint the matter, we are cowards,
And have and shall be beaten when men please
To call us into cudgelling.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I feele we are very prone that way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: The sonnes of Adam.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Now here then rests the state o'th question?
Whether we yeild our bodies for a dinner
To a sound dog-whip, for I promise ye
If men be given to correction,
We can expect no lesse, or quietly
Take a hard Egge or two, and ten mile hence
Baite in a ditch, this we may do securely;
For to stay here about will be all one,
If once our morall mischiefes come in memory.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But pray ye hear me, is not this the day
The Virgin Lady doth elect her husband?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: The dinner is to that end.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Very well then, say we all stay, and say we all scape this whipping, and be well entertained, and one of us carry the Lady.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: 'Tis a seemly saying, I must confesse, but if we stay, how fitly
We may apply it to our selves (i'th end)
Will aske a Christian feare; I cannot see
If I say true, what spetiall ornaments
Of art or nature, lay aside our lying
Whoring and drinking, which are no great vertues,
We are endued withall to win this Lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yet women go not by the best parts ever; that I have found directly.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why should we fear then? they choose men
As they feed; some times they settle
Upon a white broth'd face, a sweet smooth gallant,
And him they make an end of in a night;
Sometimes a Goose, sometimes, a grosser meat,
A rump of beef will serve 'em at some season,
And fill their bellies too: though without doubt
They are great devourers: stock fish is a dish,
If it be well drest, for the tufnesse sake
Wil make the proud'st of 'em long and leap for't.
They'l run mad for a pudding ere they'l starve,

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: For my own part I care not, come what can come,
If I be whipt, why so be it; if cudgel'd,
I hope I shall out live it, I am sure
'Tis not the hundreth time I have bin serv'd so,
And yet I thank God I am here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here's resolution.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A little patience, and a rotten Apple
Cures twenty worse diseases; what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Marry I say sir, if I had bin acquainted
With lamming in my youth, as you have bin
With whipping, and such benefits of nature,
I should do better: as I am, I'le venture,
And if it be my luck to have the Lady,
I'le use my fortune modestly; if beaten
You shall not hear a word, one I am sure of,
And if the worst fall she shall be my physick.
Lets go then, and a merry winde be with us.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Captaine your shooes are old, pray put 'em off,
And let one fling 'em after us; be bold sirs,
And howosever our fortune fals, lets beare
An equall burden; if there be an odde lash,
Wee'l part it afterwards.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I am arm'd at all points. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter foure serving in a Banquet.

sp.p: Then my Lady will have a bedfellow to night.
So she sayes, heaven what a danty armefull shall he enjoy that has the launching of her, what a fight shee'l make.
I mary boyes, there will be sport indeed, there will be grapling, she has a murderer lies in her prow, I am affraid will fright his maine mast Robin.
Who dost thou think shall have her of thy conscience, thou art a wise man.
If she go the old way, the way of lot, the longest cut sweeps all without question?
She has lost a friend of me else; what think yee of the Courtier.
Hang him hedgehogge, h'as nothing in him but a piece of Euphues, and twenty dozen of twelve penny riband all about him, he is but one Pedlers shop of gloves and garters, pickteeth and pomander.
The Courtier! marry God blesse her Steven, she is not mad yet, she knowes that trindle tayle too well, he's crest falne, and pinbuttock't with leaping Landresses.
The Merchant sure shee will not be so base to have him.
I hope so Rohin, hee'l sell us all to the Moors to make mummy; nor the Captaine.
Who Potgun, that's a sweet youth indeed, will he stay thinke ye?

Yes, without question, and have half din'd too ere the grace be done; he's good for nothing in the world but eating, lying and sleeping; what other men devour in drink, he takes in Pottage, they say has bin at Sea, a Herring fishing, for without doubt he dares not hayle an Ele-boate, ith way of War.
I think so, they would beate him off with Butter.

When he brings in a prize, unlesse it be Cockles, or Callis sand to scoure with, I'le renounce my five mark a year, and all the hidden art I have in carving, to teach young Birds to whistle Walsingham; leave him to the lime boates; now, what think you of the brave Amiens?
That's a thought indeed.
I marry ther's a person fit to feed upon a dish so danty, and hee'l do't I warrant him ith nick boyes, has a body world without end.
And such a one my Lady will make no little off; but is not Montague married to day?
Yes faith, honest Montague must have his bout too.
Hee's as good a lad as ever turnd a trencher; must we leave him?
Hee's to good for us Steven, I'le give him health to his good luck to night ith old Beaker, and it shall be sack too.
I must have a Garter; and boyes I have bespoke, a a Posset, some body shall give me thanks for't, 'tas a few toyes in't will rase commotions in a bed lad.
Away; my Lady. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Orleance, and his Lady arme in arme, Amiens, Lamira, Charlote, like a Bride, Montague brave, Laverdine, Longavile Dubois, Mallycorn, La-Poope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stur your selves noble Lords and Gentlemen,
You know your places; many royall welcomes
I give your grace; how lovely shewes this change?
My house is honor'd in this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thus Madam must you do, my Lady now shall see
You made a Woman;
And give you some short lessons for your voyage.
Take her instructions Lady, she knowes much.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: This becomes you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My Lord must have his will.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Tis all I can do now sweet heart, faire Lady;
This to your happy choyce brother Amiens,
You are the man I meane it to.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I'le pledge you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And with my heart.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: With all my love I take it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Noble Lords I am proud ye have done this day,
so much content, and me such estimation that this hour
(In this poor house) shall be a league for ever,
For so I know ye mean it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I do Lady.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Y'ave done a work of honor.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Give me the Cup, where this health stops, let
That man be either very sick, or very simple;
Or I am very angry; sir, to you;
Madam me thinks this Gentleman might sit to;
He would become the best on's.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pray sit down sir, I know the Lady of the feast expects not this day so much old custom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down Mountague; nay never blush for the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Noble Madam, I have too reasons against it, and I dare not; duty to you first, as you are my Lady, and I your poorest servant; next the custome of this dayes ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: As you are my servant, I may command you then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: To my life Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down, and here, I'le have it so.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Sit down man, never refuse so faire a Ladies offer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It is your pleasure Madam, not my pride,
And I obey; Ile pledge yee now my Lord, Mounsier Longavile.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This to my Lady, and her faire choyce to day, and happinesse.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Tis a faire health, I'le pledge you though I sinke for't.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Montague you are too modest; come I'le adde a little more wine t'ee, 'twill make you merry, this to the good I wish.—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Honord Lady, I shall forget my selfe with this great bounty.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: You shall not sir; give him some Vine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By heaven you are a worthy woman, and that
Man is blest can come neer such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Such a blessing wet weather washes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: At all, I will not go a lip lesse my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Tis well cast sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If Montague get more Wine, we are like to heare on't.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I do not like that sitting there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, me thinks he looks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now have I a kinde a grudging of a beating on me, I fear my hot fit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Drink apace, ther's nothing allays a cudgell like it.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, now I'le put my choyce to you; who do you hold in all this honor'd company a husband fit to enjoy thy Lady? speak directly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Shall I speak Madam?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, you shall.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then as I have a soule I'le speak my conscience,
Give me more wine, in vino veritas,
Here's to my self, and Montague have a care.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Speak to th'cause.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; first I'le begin to thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Have at us.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now for a Psalme of mercy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You good Mounsier, you that bely the noble Name of Courtier, and think your claime good here, hold up your hand; your Worship is endited here, for a vaine glorious foole.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good, oh sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For one whose wit
Lies in a ten pound wastcoat, yet not warme;
Ye have travel'd like a Fidler to make faces,
And brought home nothing but a case of tooth-picks.
You would be married, and no lesse then Ladies,
And of the best sort can serve you; thou silke worm
What hast thou in thee to deserve this woman?
Name but the poorest piece of man, good manners,
Ther's nothing sound about thee, faith thou'ast none,
It lies pawn'd at thy silke mans, for so much lace;
Thy credit which is worse cannot redeem it,
Thy cloaths are all the soule thou hast, for so
Thou sav'st them hansome for the next great tilting
Let who wil take the t'other, thou wert never christen'd
Upon my conscience (but in barbers water)
Thou art never out o'th basen, thou art rotten,
And if thou darst tell truth, thou wilt confesse it;
— thy skin
Looks of a Chestnut colour, greas'd with Amber
All women that on earth do dwell thou lov'st,
Yet none that understand love thee again,
But those that love the Spittle, get thee home
Poor painted butter fly, thy summers pa'st;
Go sweat and eat dry Mutton, thou mayst live
To do so well yet; a bruis'd Chamber Maide
May fall upon thee, and advance thy follies.
You have your sentence; now it followes Captaine,
I treat of you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Pray God I may deserve it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Beshrow my heart he speaks, plaine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: That's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You are a rascall Captaine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A fine calling.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A water coward.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: He would make a prety stuffe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nay I speak freely Madam.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Her's none ties you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why should'st thou dare come hither with a thought
To finde a wife here fit for thee? are all
Thy single money whores that fed on Carrots,
And fild the high grasse with familiars
Falne of to footmen? prethee tell me truly,
For now I know thou dar'st not lie, couldst thou not
Wish thy selfe beaten well with all thy heart now,
And out of paine? say that I broke a rib,
Or cut thy nose off, wert not mercifull for this ambition?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Do your pleasure sir, beggars must not be choosers.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He longs for beating.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But that I have nobler thoughts possesse my soule,
Then such brown bisket, such a peice of dog-fish,
Such a most mangy Mackrell eater as thou art
That dares do nothing that belongs toth' Sea,
But spue, and catch rats, and fear men of war,
Though thou hast nothing in the world to loose
Abord thee, but one piece of beefe, one Musket
Without a cock for peace sake, and a pitch barrell,
I'le tell thee if my time were not more pretious
Then thus to loose it, I would rattle thee,
It may be beat thee, and thy pure fellow,
The Merchant there of Catskins, till my words,
Or blowes, or both, made ye two branded wretches
To all the world hereafter; you would faine to
Venture your bils of lading for this Lady;
What would you give now for her? some five frayle
Of rotten Figs good, Godson, would you not sir?
Or a Parrat that speaks high Dutch? can all thou ever saw'st
Of thine own fraughts from Sea, or cosonage
(At which thou art as expert as the devill)
Nay sell thy soul for wealth to, as thou wilt do,
Forfeit thy friends, and raise a mint of Money,
Make thee dream all these double could procure
A kisse from this good Lady? can'st thou hope
She would lie with such a nook of hell as thou art,
And hatch young Merchant-furies? oh ye dog-bolts
That fear no God but Dunkirks, I shall see you
Serve in a lowsy Lime boat, ere I die,
For mouldy cheese and butter Billingsgate
Would not endure, or bring in rotten Pippins
To cure blew eyes, and swear they came from China.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Vex 'em no more, alas they shake:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Down quickly on your marrow bones▪ and thank this Lady.
I would not leave you thus else, there are blankets,
And such delights for such knaves; but fear still;
'Twill be revenge enough, to keep you waking.
Ye have no minde of Marriage, ha' ye?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Surely no great mind now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Nor you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, I take it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Two eager sutors.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Troth tis wonderous hot, God blesse us from him

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: You have told me Montague
Who are not fit to have me, let me know
The man you would point out for me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: There he sits; my Lord of Amiens, Madam, is my choyce, hee's noble every way, and worthy a wife with all the dowries of—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you speak sir out of your friendship to me?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and out of truth, for I could never flatter.

sp.speaker: Ami
sp.l: I would not say how much I owe you for it,
For that were but a promise, but Ile thank ye,
As now I find you, in despite of fortune,
A faire and noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: My Lords I must confesse the choyce this man hath made
Is every way a great one, if not too great,
And no way to be slighted: yet because
We love to have our own eyes, sometimes now
Give me a little liberty to see,
How I could fit my selfe, if I were put to't.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Madam we must.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Are yee all agreed?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We be?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Then as I am a maid, I shall choose here.
Montague, I must have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why Madam I have learnt to suffer more then you can (out of pitty) mock me with this way especially.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Thou think'st I jest now;
But by the love I bear thee, I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you could be so weak, to love a falne man,
He must deserve more then I ever can,
Or ever shall (deer Lady;) look but this way
Upon that Lord and you will tell me then
Your eyes are no true choosers of good men.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you love him truely?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I will obey him truly, for I'le marry him, and justly thinke he that has so well serv'd mee with his obedience being borne to greatnesse, must use mee nobly of necessity when I shall serve him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: 'Twere a deepe sin to crosse ye, noble Montague,
I wish ye all content, and am as happy
In my friends good as it were meerly mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your Lordship does ill to give up your right;
I am not capable of this great goodnesse,
There sits my wife that holds my troth.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'le end all, I wooed you for my Lady, and now give up my title, alas poor wench, my aimes are lower far.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How's this sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Sweet heart tis so, the drift was mine to hide
My purpose till it struck home.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Prethee leave wondring, by this kisse I'le have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Then by this kisse, and this I'le ever serve ye.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This Gentleman and I sir must needs hop once more to follow yee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: As friends and fellows, never as servants more.

sp.speaker: Long. Dub.
sp.p: You make us happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Friend Montague, ye have taught mee so much honor, I have found a fault in my self, but thus I'le purge my conscience of it, the late land I took by false play, from you with as much Contrition, and entirenesse of affection to this most happy day again, I render; be Master of your own, forget my malice, and make mee worthy of your love, L. Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You have won me and honor to your name.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Since your Lordship has begun good deeds, wee'l follow; good sir forgive us, we are now those men fear you for goodnes sake; those sums of money unjustly we detaine from you, on your pardon shall bee restord again, and we your servants.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: You are very forward sir, it seems you have money, I pray you lay out, I'le pay you or pray for you, as the Sea works.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Their pennance sir I'le undertake, so please ye
To grant me on concealement.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Right courtier, still a begging.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What is it sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: In my gift?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Yes sir, in yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why bring her forth and take her.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: What wench would he have?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Any wench I think.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Veramour, like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: This is the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis my Page sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No sir, I am a poor disguis'd Lady?
That like a Page have followed you full long for love god-wot.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A Lady— Laverdine— yes, yes, tis a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It may be so, and yet we have laine together,
But by my troth I never found her, Lady.

sp.speaker: L Orl.
sp.l: Why wore you boyes cloathes?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I'le tell you Madam,
I took example by 2 or 3. playes, that methought
Concernd me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why made you not me acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed sir I knew it not my selfe,
Untill this Gentleman opend my dull eyes,
And by perswasion made me see it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Could his power in words make such a change?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, as truly woman as your selfe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why but hark you, are not you a woman?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If hands and face make it not evident, you shall see more.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Breeches, breeches, Laverdine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Tis not enough, women may wear those cases.
Search further Courtier.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Oh thou freshwater Gudgeon, wouldst thou come
To point of Marriage with an Ignoramus?
Thou shouldst have had her urin to the doctors,
The foolishest Phisitian could have made plaine
The liquid Epicaene; a blind man by the hand
Could have discoverd the ring from the stone.
Boy, come, to Sea with me, Ile teach thee to climb,
And come down by the rope, nay to eate Rats.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I shall devour my Master before the prison then,
Sir, I have began my Trade.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Trade? to the Citie, child, a flatcap will become thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Gentlemen I beseech you molest your selves no further,
For his preferment it is determin'd.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am much ashamed, and if my cheek
Gives not satisfaction, break my head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your shame's enough sir.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Montague, much joy attend thy marriage Bed;
By thy example of true goodnesse, envie is exil'd,
And to all honest men that truth intend,
I wish good luck, faire fate be still thy friend.

div.head: Vpon an Honest Mans Fortune.
div.l: YOu that can look through Heaven, and tell the Stars,
Observe their kind conjunctions, and their wars;
Find out new lights, and give them where you please,
To those men honors, pleasures, to those ease;
You that are Gods surveyers, and can show
How far, and when, and why the wind doth blow;
Know all the charges of the dreadfull thunder,
And when it will shoot over, or fall under:
Tell me, by all your art I conjure ye,
Yes, and by truth, what shall become of me?
Find out my star, if each one, as you say,
Have his peculiar Angel, and his way;
Observe my fate, next fall into your dreames,
Sweep clean your houses, and new line your sceames,
Then say your worst: or have I none at all?
Or is it burnt out lately? or did fall?
Or am I poor, not able, no full flame?
My star, like me, unworthy of a name?
Is it, your art can only work on those
That deale with dangers, dignities, and cloaths?
With love, or new opinions? you all lye,
A fishwife hath a fate, and so have I,
But far above your finding; he that gives,
Out of his providence, to all that lives,
And no man knowes his treasure, no not you:
He that made Egypt blind, from whence you grew
Scaby and lowsy, that the world might see
Your calculations are as blind as ye,
He that made all the stars, you dayly read,
And from thence filtch a knowledge how to feed;
Hath hid this from you, your conjectures all
Are drunken things, not how, but when they fall;
Man is his own star, and the soule that can
Render an honest, and a perfect man
Command all light, all influence, all fate,
Nothing to him fals early or too late.
Our acts our Angels arc, or good or ill,
Our fatall shadowes that walke by us still,
And when the stars are labouring, we believe
Jt is not that they govern, but they grive
For stubborn ignorance; all things that are
Made for our generall uses are at war,
Even we among our selves, and from the strife
Your first unlike opinions got a life.
O man, thou image of thy makers good,
What canst thou fear, when breath'd into thy blood
His spirit is, that built thee? what dull sence
Makes thee suspect, in need, that providence?
Who made the morning, and who plact the light
Guid to thy labours? who cal'd up the night,
And bid her fall upon thee, like sweet showers
In hollow murmurs, to lock up thy powers?
Who gave thee knowledge, who so trusted thee,
To let thee grow so neer himselfe, the Tree?
Must he then be distrusted? shall his frame
Discourse with him, why thus, and thus I am?
He made the Angels thine, thy fellowes all,
Nay even thy servants, when devotions call.
Oh canst thou be so stupid then, so dim,
To seek a saving influence, and loose him?
Can Stars protect thee? or can poverty,
Which is the light to Heaven, put out his eye?
He is my star, in him all truth I find,
All influence, all fate, and when my mind
Is furnished with his fullnesse, my poor story
Shall outlive all their Age, and all their glory.
The hand of danger cannot fall amisse,
When I know what, and in whose power it is.
Nor Want, the cause of man, shall make me groan,
A holy hermit is a mind alone.
Doth not experience teach us all we can
To work our selves into a glorious man?
Love's but an exhalation to best eyes
The matter spent, and then the fooles fire dyes?
Were I in love, and could that bright star bring
Increase to wealth, honour, and every thing:
Were she as perfect good as wee can aime,
The first was so, and yet she lost the Game.
My mistris then be knowledge and faire truth;
So I enjoy all beauty and all youth,
And though to time her lights and lawes she lends,
She knowes no Age that to corruption bends.
Friends promises may lead me to believe,
But he that is his own friend knowes to live.
Affliction when J know it is but this,
A deep allay whereby man tougher is
To bear the hammer, and the deeper still,
We still arise more image of his will.
Sicknesse an humorous cloud twixt us and light,
And Death, at longest but another night.
Man is his own Star, and that soule that can
Be honest is the only perfect man.
